Jung won the Olympic equestrian eventing gold aboard Sam, a late replacement for the infected Fischertakinou, with France's Astier Nicolas earning silver and American Phillip Dutton taking bronze, while Great Britain's William Fox-Pitt finished 12th just 10 months after an induced coma from a fall; the three-time Olympian led after dressage but dropped due to cross-country time penalties despite a faultless show-jumping phase. Ireland's Jonty Evans placed ninth on Cooley Rorkes Drift. The passage also promotes visiting Team GB fan parks to ride mechanical horse Henry, a guide to getting into equestrian, and subscribing to the BBC Sport newsletter.

Andy Murray, the 30-year-old Briton, defeated 29th seed Fabio Fognini 6-2, 4-6, 6-1, 7-5 in a tense Wimbledon match lasting two hours and 39 minutes, clinching match point at 20:57 BST and advancing to the last 16 for the 11th time by winning five straight games after Fognini had five set points to force a decider. Despite an up-and-down performance marked by fading light, Fognini's comeback in the second set, an ankle injury, and on-court drama including a point penalty for obscenity, Murray fought back from 5-2 down in the fourth set to avoid a fifth set that would have required the roof or a Saturday resumption. Murray expressed relief at finishing in four sets, noted he didn't move as well as in prior matches but felt OK with time to prepare for his fourth-round match against Benoit Paire on Monday, while fellow Briton Johanna Konta reached the second week for the first time with a 6-4, 6-1 win over Maria Sakkari.

Paramedics responded to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014, where police later discovered people still present and till receipts indicating alcohol served until 04:49 BST, leading a judge at Limavady Magistrates Court to order the bar's closure for three months. Colleen O'Neill, 43, the license holder from Kevin Lynch Park, faced two charges of allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours and was fined £3,000, while James Thomas, 44, from the same address, faced one such charge and was fined £1,000. The defence noted that local licensing laws were not strictly followed and the bar operated improperly into the morning, with the judge describing O'Neill's record as appalling and the case as one of the worst, though he lacked authority for a custodial sentence.

Mike Nesbitt, leader of the Ulster Unionists, launched the party's 'Real Partnership' manifesto, emphasizing that "domination doesn't work, partnership does" and framing the election as a referendum on the Renewable Heat Incentive scandal, criticizing DUP and Sinn Féin's decade in power for incompetence, arrogance, cronyism, and potential corruption, including £85,000 daily losses. Amid controversy over his remarks encouraging vote transfers to the SDLP over Sinn Féin for post-election partnerships at Stormont, Nesbitt defended his stance without regret, noting positive feedback from unionist areas and allowing party candidates flexibility on transfers. The manifesto proposes tackling health waiting lists, boosting PSNI numbers to 7,500, prioritizing the York Street interchange, supporting the LGBT community, ensuring no group suffers from Brexit, and cleaning up Stormont governance.

Justice Minister Claire Sugden has confirmed that a motion will be presented to the Northern Ireland assembly for approval, aiming to align the region with England and Wales by introducing automatic posthumous pardons for men convicted of now-abolished sexual offences, under provisions dubbed 'Turing's Law' after Alan Turing. The motion will also allow living gay and bisexual men convicted of such offences to apply for pardons, with executive agreement secured for a legislative consent motion to ensure equal treatment. Sugden stated that this approach will enable quicker resolution to right past wrongs in the criminal justice system compared to a full assembly bill, and arrangements will be implemented as soon as possible.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old from Kinross, finished second in a mile race behind Kenyan Faith Kipyegon with a time of 4:19.12 seconds, breaking Yvonne Murray's 1994 Scottish record of 4:22.60 and placing her second on the British all-time list behind Zola Budd's 4:17.57. Muir, who holds the Scottish 1500m and mile records and finished fifth in last year's World Championships, expressed delight at the achievement in her first race of the season at this distance, noting her excitement at running close to Kipyegon. Yvonne Murray congratulated Muir via her husband on Facebook. Muir, who balances training with her veterinary studies and recently completed her fourth year, started her season with an 800m win in Montbeliard, France, and aims to secure a spot on Great Britain's Olympic team at the British trials in Birmingham from June 24-26, with her next race being a 1500m in Stockholm in a week.
The passage introduces a selection of pictures from 26 beaches in Scotland that have been ranked as the "most excellent" for their water quality.

Richard Horwell QC, barrister for the Met Police, stated in closing remarks at an inquiry that Russian suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi had no personal motive to kill Alexander Litvinenko but likely acted under sponsorship from the Russian state, which had ample reasons including viewing his 2000 defection to the UK, accusations against the FSB, and personal attacks on Vladimir Putin as treachery. Litvinenko, 43, was poisoned twice with radioactive polonium-210 in tea during a 2006 London meeting with the suspects, leading to his death three weeks later in hospital, with evidence of a polonium trail left by the pair indicating state involvement though not necessarily by Putin himself. The attacks caused great suffering, posed unknown long-term radiation risks to the London public, and while the suspects deny wrongdoing and remain in Russia despite failed extradition attempts, they lack credible answers to scientific evidence; Kovtun was criticized for not testifying, and the inquiry was adjourned until Friday.

Steve Smith, 26, has been appointed as Australia's new Test captain, succeeding Michael Clarke, 34, who retired after the team's Ashes defeat to England at Trent Bridge, giving the hosts a 3-1 lead. Smith, who already leads the one-day side and will captain the Twenty20 team without the injured Aaron Finch, previously skippered three Tests against India during Clarke's injury recovery. National selector Rod Marsh praised Smith as a talented young leader with 32 Tests, 2,952 runs at an average of 54.66, noting he has big shoes to fill but is the right choice. David Warner, 28, was named vice-captain, with Marsh highlighting his maturity and growth into a senior figure despite past disciplinary issues. Smith and Warner will lead in the upcoming limited-overs matches following the final Ashes Test at the Oval starting August 20.

Tim Farron, who recently became leader of the Liberal Democrats by defeating Norman Lamb, repeatedly refused to directly answer whether he believes homosexual sex is a sin, instead stating that "we are all sinners," while emphasizing his passion for LGBT+ rights and prioritizing the defense and extension of equal marriage laws. He highlighted the need to address the spousal veto, which requires consent from a spouse for a transgender person's marriage to continue after gender change, ensuring equal marital access. Farron explained his 2007 vote against the Equality Bill, which aimed to prevent discrimination against gay people by businesses, stemmed from concerns over individual liberties after a Lib Dem amendment was defeated, but affirmed his strong support for equality and equal legal access regardless of sexuality.

In 2015, French-based Sanofi closed its drug manufacturing site in Fawdon, resulting in the loss of 450 jobs, but Accord Healthcare now plans to repurpose the plant for its pharmaceutical production, with hopes of rehiring many former Sanofi employees. A company spokesman expressed confidence that the investment would have an "extremely positive" impact on the area, while Newcastle City Council leader Councillor Nick Forbes hailed it as fantastic news for Newcastle and the North East, enhancing the region's reputation in science and healthcare, and providing highly skilled jobs and long-term economic boosts. Accord Healthcare, a global pharmaceutical player, develops, manufactures, and distributes over 130 products to around 60 countries worldwide.

The local authority announced that Richard Ellis, the former interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive, is leaving on Friday at the end of his contract, while Ciaran Monaghan, head of the chief executive's office, and Ewan Sutherland, head of human resources and customer services, are departing under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. Opposition SNP group leader Stephen Flynn described the departures as evidence of the council's failure to retain senior staff, predicting more exits in the coming months. Council chief executive Angela Scott expressed thanks to the trio for their dedication and professionalism.

Militants armed with guns and grenades attacked Kabul's Sardar Daud hospital by detonating explosives at the gate and firing on staff and patients, killing at least several people and wounding over 50 in an assault claimed by the Islamic State (IS), which the Taliban denied involvement in. Afghan commandos landed on the roof and killed all four attackers after more than six hours of fighting, with President Ashraf Ghani condemning the 09:00 local time attack as a violation of human values and an assault on all of Afghanistan. Eyewitnesses described gunmen disguised in white coats shooting indiscriminately, while the incident marks a tactical shift for IS in Afghanistan, adopting Taliban-style methods for their first direct clash with security forces in the capital, potentially signaling expanded capabilities amid ongoing rivalries and previous attacks on civilians, Shia gatherings, and sites like the Supreme Court since IS established its presence in 2015.

English rider Guy Martin crashed at this year's TT on the mechanically troubled Fireblade bike, initially telling MCN he was quitting road racing before clarifying on Facebook that he hasn't given up on racing or road racing but has no plans for more road racing on Hondas this year. He skipped the North West 200 after teammate John McGuinness's practice crash and will not compete in next month's Ulster Grand Prix, describing the TT as a disaster where he only enjoyed walking the dog and racing the Mugen, while feeling like a test rider amid clear pre-event struggles. Following further testing at Cadwell, he informed the team the bike wouldn't be competitive at the Ulster GP, leading to his withdrawal without prior notice, which he accepted, stating there's no unfinished business and he wants to focus on racing classics and oddball events.

In Nigeria's recent gubernatorial elections, the All Progressives Congress (APC) secured 19 out of 28 governor positions, marking the Peoples Democratic Party's (PDP) most significant defeat since 1999, following its loss in the presidential race to APC's Muhammadu Buhari, who will be inaugurated on May 29 after defeating incumbent Goodluck Jonathan. The PDP retained eight governorships, primarily in the south-east, and held onto oil-rich Rivers State, but lost key northern states like Katsina, Kaduna, and Adamawa amid Boko Haram's insurgency; results remain outstanding in Taraba and inconclusive in Imo, with no elections in seven states. The APC achieved historic gains, controlling the north and commercial hub Lagos for the first time under a president's party since multi-party democracy began, though it failed to win any of the five oil-producing states, raising concerns for Buhari about potential militant disruptions to oil revenue. Elections saw 66 violent incidents, mainly in southern states like Rivers, fueled by rivalry, ethnic tensions, power struggles, and money, yet were more peaceful overall, signaling maturing democracy. The PDP's decline stems from defections, corruption allegations, and failures in addressing the north-east insurgency, necessitating introspection and rebuilding as it becomes a regional force confined to the south-east and Niger Delta.

A US-based environmental group, Mighty, accuses Singapore-based agricultural trader Olam and its majority stakeholder, Temasek (a Singapore state-owned investment firm), of enabling unsustainable palm oil practices that contribute to regional haze from slash-and-burn fires in Indonesia's Riau, South Sumatra, and Kalimantan regions, by sourcing from rogue suppliers and creating a secretive market for such oil. Olam, which buys 99% of its palm oil from third-party suppliers and holds less than 1% of the global market, rejects the claims, citing its strict 'no burn-no peat-no deforestation' policy, recent disclosure of 14 suppliers, and ongoing vetting process to ensure compliance, with non-compliant producers to be removed. Temasek also dismisses the allegations, supporting no-burn policies but stating it does not direct Olam's operations. The report further criticizes Olam for bulldozing rainforests in Gabon for monoculture plantations, mirroring destructive practices in Southeast Asia, though Olam defends these as responsible, transparent public-private partnerships aligned with Gabon's rights to convert minimal forested land. The palm oil industry faces broader scrutiny for deforestation, illegal labor, and environmental harm, with tensions between NGOs advocating stricter enforcement and executives highlighting challenges in policing suppliers amid economic benefits to rural areas.

On 27 August 2016, updated at 12:34 BST, a restaurant started serving puppy platters following the introduction of a new law that permits dogs to eat at restaurants provided they are outdoors, with the setup described as looking like a "right dog's dinner" and a clip available for viewing.

Forward Fernando Forestieri is doubtful due to a knee issue, having only featured from the bench in the last two games, while Derby County striker David Nugent may return from a groin injury after missing Monday's draw with Huddersfield, and midfielder Jacob Butterfield hopes for a starting spot after substituting in to score a late equalizer against the Terriers.

Pakistan's telecom regulator lifted a three-year ban on YouTube after Google launched a localized version for the country, allowing the Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA) to directly request blocking of offending material, which Google will restrict for Pakistani users following review. The ban, imposed by the Supreme Court in 2012 over the anti-Islam film "Innocence of Muslims" that sparked deadly protests, is no longer deemed necessary. YouTube denied claims of government filtering capabilities, stating that content removal requests are not automatically granted but evaluated against community guidelines and local laws, with such requests logged in its Transparency Report. While many young Pakistanis welcomed the move, activists demanded greater transparency on the agreement terms between Google and the government. The PTA directed internet providers to restore access, and Google also introduced local YouTube versions for Nepal and Sri Lanka.

Domenico Scala, the Swiss-Italian head of FIFA's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, faces calls to withdraw from overseeing the upcoming presidential election due to shared nationality with candidate Gianni Infantino, similar to his voluntary recusal in 2015 to avoid any appearance of conflict with incumbent Swiss candidate Sepp Blatter. Liberian FA boss Musa Bility, who was barred from running after failing an eligibility check and now supports Prince Ali, has threatened to take the matter to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not step down by Thursday, citing FIFA's Electoral Regulations on conflicts of interest. A spokesman for Scala insists there is no actual conflict under the rules, as there is no incumbent president this time, and the previous withdrawal was precautionary. The election on February 26 in Zurich, voted on by FIFA's 209 members, features five candidates—Infantino, Prince Ali, Jerome Champagne, Sheikh Salman, and Tokyo Sexwale—to replace long-standing president Blatter amid FIFA's recent turmoil, with Bility emphasizing the need for fairness and integrity in the process.

Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were killed in an incident at Harford Attachments in Spar Road shortly after 09:00 BST on Monday while working in a paint-spraying area at the company, which manufactures buckets for diggers. Their bodies were removed from the site on Tuesday afternoon following a forensic search. Det Ch Insp Paul Durham reported significant progress in forensic inquiries and witness statements, with evidence indicating a flashover explosion caused by a build-up of toxic fumes combined with an ignition source, resulting in a fire-ball effect. The Health and Safety Executive stated that its inspectors and electrical safety experts are gathering evidence.

Tunisia avoided expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations by apologizing to CAF for complaints about a controversial penalty in their 2015 quarter-final loss to hosts Equatorial Guinea, which led to a 2-1 extra-time defeat and accusations of poor referee selection rather than corruption; a meeting with CAF president Issa Hayatou resolved the issue, allowing Tunisia to join Group A qualifiers against Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti, potentially marking their record 13th straight finals appearance. Meanwhile, Morocco regained entry into the 2017 qualifiers after the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned CAF's ban and reduced a $1 million fine to $50,000, stemming from their refusal to host the 2015 tournament due to Ebola fears, with Equatorial Guinea stepping in as last-minute hosts; Morocco's FA expressed optimism and will face Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome in Group F.

Following a mass fracas in the 95th minute of the match at Etihad Stadium, which Chelsea won 3-1, Manchester City players Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho were sent off, with Aguero receiving a four-match ban for his second violent conduct dismissal this season after a high and late challenge on Chelsea's David Luiz, and Fernandinho earning a three-match ban for clashing with Chelsea's Cesc Fabregas during the ensuing scuffle. Fabregas faces no further action, City manager Pep Guardiola apologized for his team's involvement, and both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge.

Wales and parts of the UK have some of the worst cancer survival rates in the developed world, prompting a pilot scheme in Cwm Cynon and Neath to focus on patients suspected of cancer by GPs but lacking urgent symptoms, inspired by Denmark's successful diagnostic systems visited by Welsh experts a year ago. The concern is that such patients face prolonged waits for diagnosis due to not fitting specific treatment pathways, leading to repeated referrals and tests over weeks, potentially allowing cancer to advance untreated. Under the pilot, 40 GPs in Cwm Cynon can refer patients to a diagnostic center at Royal Glamorgan Hospital in Llantrisant within seven days, with around six patients weekly receiving various tests ideally on the same day; a similar clinic is planned for Neath Port Talbot. Currently, only 35% of patients with concerning symptoms receive diagnoses in Cwm Taf, and the scheme aims to accelerate access for those without obvious signs. If the six-month Cwm Cynon pilot succeeds, it will expand to other local health boards, offering quicker diagnoses, peace of mind, and potentially life-saving early interventions, as highlighted by experts like Dr. Gareth Davies and GP Gareth Jordan.

England secured a dominant victory over Pakistan in the second Test at Old Trafford, winning with a day to spare to level the four-match series, posting 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared while bowling Pakistan out for 198 and 234, marking their second-biggest win by runs against them. Joe Root, promoted to number three, earned man-of-the-match honors with 254 in the first innings, an unbeaten 71 off 48 balls in the second, four catches, and a wicket, receiving high praise from captain Alastair Cook, coach Trevor Bayliss, and Michael Vaughan for his controlled and exceptional performance after addressing errors from the first Test loss. Pakistan struggled on a flat pitch, batting only 63 and 70 overs respectively, with their spirit deemed broken by Geoffrey Boycott, who predicted England would dominate the series, though Vaughan anticipated a tight contest overall. Pakistan captain Misbah-ul-Haq expressed disappointment over poor shot selection and lack of confidence but remained hopeful for a strong response, ahead of a tour game against Worcestershire and the third Test at Edgbaston starting August 3.

Warren Gatland is head coach of the British and Irish Lions touring New Zealand, with Rob Howley named as interim coach in his backroom team, while forwards coach McBryde will take on head coach duties for Wales' summer tour for the third time, following previous stints in 2009 and 2013. McBryde expressed excitement and honor in leading the team overseas, having enjoyed it previously. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) plans to appoint assistant coaches to support McBryde, with chief executive Martyn Phillips noting advanced discussions and an expected confirmation of the full management team next week. WRU chairman Gareth Davies highlighted the benefits for Welsh rugby, describing 2017 as a summer of opportunity for coaches to develop in new environments, with the Lions' New Zealand tour providing the ultimate test to stimulate and inspire participants, building on invigorating past experiences.

Hull City secured a 2-1 comeback victory over Southampton in the Premier League, ending a six-game losing streak but remaining in the bottom three. Southampton took an early lead through Charlie Austin's sixth-minute penalty after Curtis Davies fouled Maya Yoshida, but Hull suffered first-half injuries to strikers Abel Hernandez and Will Keane, prompting the introduction of Robert Snodgrass, who transformed the game. Snodgrass scored the equalizer in the 61st minute from Sam Clucas' cross and assisted Michael Dawson's headed winner from a free-kick two minutes later. Southampton pressed for an equalizer, with goalkeeper David Marshall making key saves and Clucas executing a dramatic goalline clearance in added time. Hull manager Mike Phelan praised his team's resilience and Snodgrass' character despite a recent ankle injury, while Southampton's Claude Puel highlighted a lack of concentration post their Europa League win over Inter Milan. Hull next face Sunderland, and Southampton host Liverpool after the international break.

A motorcyclist was killed in a collision with a tractor at approximately 14:15 BST on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa, according to Lincolnshire Police, who noted the victim lived locally but released no further details. The tractor driver was uninjured, and police have appealed for witnesses to come forward. The B1191 was closed in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction in Woodhall Spa and the A158 Jubilee Way junction in Horncastle.

Macedonian President Ivanov cancelled an investigation into abuse of power claims from 2015 covert recordings, citing the need to end national agony ahead of June early elections and defend interests, a move he described as cutting a knot. The decision drew condemnation from opposition leader Zoran Zaev, who called it illegal and urged protests in Skopje, where hundreds gathered, as well as from EU Enlargement Commissioner Johannes Hahn, who stated it violated rule of law and jeopardized Macedonia's EU membership ambitions. The ongoing crisis stems from Zaev's release of recordings allegedly exposing government wiretapping of 20,000 people, vote-rigging, corruption, mismanagement of funds, dubious prosecutions, and cover-ups of murders and killings, accusations denied by the government, which counters that Zaev aims to destabilize the nation.

Following Bob Bradley's sacking, Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will oversee Swansea City's match against Bournemouth, as the club aims to swiftly appoint a new manager, with ex-Derby boss Paul Clement as the top choice to help avoid relegation from the Premier League. Curtis warns that dropping to the Championship would be challenging, given its increased competitiveness and no guarantee of a quick return, unlike clubs like Newcastle that can retain top players. Swansea, promoted to the Premier League in 2011 after nearly facing bankruptcy and Football League relegation in 2003, built a reputation for well-run operations and exciting possession-based football under managers like Roberto Martinez, Brendan Rodgers, and Michael Laudrup. However, Curtis believes the club has lost its 'Swansea Way' since Laudrup's 2014 departure due to frequent managerial changes, player losses without adequate replacements, and a dilution of their identity. He asserts the current squad is capable of survival and reminds new signings, especially foreign players, of the club's remarkable rise via the documentary "Jack to a King," emphasizing the importance of staying up for the club and the local area.

Dagenham & Redbridge were relegated to the National League after a 3-2 defeat to Leyton Orient, with Orient's goals from Jay Simpson (two) and Armand Gnanduillet securing the win despite replies from Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona, keeping Orient's play-off hopes alive just two points adrift. The Daggers, who entered the Football League in 2007 and reached League One in 2010 under manager John Still, return to non-league under the same boss, hampered this season by League Two's worst goal difference, conceding 20 more goals than last term, and a struggling attack where 40-year-old Cureton scored only nine goals compared to 20 in 2014-15. Still, back for his third spell since December, vowed to help the club gain promotion next season, while Orient's interim manager Andy Hessenthaler, dealing with the recent removal of player-manager Kevin Nolan, emphasized professionalism and the need to win for play-off contention despite a nervy performance.

Steven Gerrard, the 36-year-old former Liverpool captain, is set to return to the club as a youth coach in February, marking his first role since retiring as a player in November after a 19-year career. Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp described the appointment as "wonderful news" following a positive chat, noting Gerrard's ambition to become a manager in the future and his readiness to learn, combining his experience with necessary skills for a bright future in football. Gerrard, who debuted for Liverpool in 1998 and won the Champions League, UEFA Cup, FA Cup, and League Cup (three times) before joining LA Galaxy in 2015, turned down an opportunity to manage League One side MK Dons as it came "too soon," and he is currently pursuing his UEFA A coaching licence required for Premier League management.

Morton secured a comfortable victory over Alloa, opening the scoring through McManus' close-range goal on the quarter-hour mark, followed quickly by Ross Forbes' deflected strike to double the lead. Alloa pulled one back before half-time via Kyle McAusland's shot, but McManus netted again and Denny Johnstone added a late goal to seal the win for the hosts.

Ofsted has uncovered evidence of children being taught in squalid conditions at three illegal schools in Birmingham, which have now been closed, with owners under investigation and facing potential jail terms of up to 51 weeks. Chief Inspector Sir Michael Wilshaw described the findings as the "tip of the iceberg," expressing concerns about risks of abuse and radicalization, particularly in 18 unregulated schools visited mainly in Muslim communities in the Midlands. Places teaching over 20 hours a week must register as schools, but some exploit home education laws to operate illegally; Ofsted criticized officials for slow action and confusing advice. The government is funding a team of inspectors to investigate such sites across all religious groups, with the education secretary pushing for prosecutions and consulting on tighter regulations for settings teaching 6-8 hours weekly, running until mid-January.

Lilliard Gin is a new small-scale distillery based at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, Scottish Borders, operating from a cowshed with one of the UK's smallest production stills, and it precedes proposals for the region's first whisky distillery since 1837. Lead distiller Kate Macinnes highlights the excitement of establishing the Borders as a distilling excellence hub, using local wild botanicals from the Teviot valley to capture the area's unique terroir and flavor. John Henderson of Born in the Borders notes it's a fitting companion to their on-site brewery, marking the first new distillery in nearly 200 years and aligning with their local sourcing ethos. The gin is named after Lilliard, a legendary heroine from the 1545 Battle of Ancrum Moor near the site, who fought to avenge her lover's death, reflecting the local landscape and the distillery's strong female team.

Harry Whitlam was killed in August 2013 when Gary Green, 51, from Wakefield, who was more than twice the legal alcohol limit after consuming the equivalent of 13 pints of beer, reversed a tractor into him at Swithens Farm in Rothwell, near Leeds, on private land. Green, prosecuted under health and safety laws rather than road traffic regulations, admitted failing to ensure others' safety and was jailed for 16 months and two weeks, with the HSE describing his reckless behavior as leading to an extremely tragic incident. Harry's mother, Pam Whitlam, a farm cafe worker, expressed that the close-knit family has been forever changed, emphasizing that driving drunk is unacceptable anywhere, and hopes to remember Harry's full life beyond the accident, as they continue to miss him deeply.

Luis Suarez, the 27-year-old Uruguay striker who joined Barcelona for £75m, has had his appeal against a four-month FIFA ban for biting Italy's Giorgio Chiellini during the 2014 World Cup partially upheld by CAS, allowing him to train with his new team starting Friday, play in friendlies, attend matches, and participate in promotional activities, though he remains barred from organized competitive games. He will be presented at Camp Nou on Monday and may feature in a friendly against Club Leon, with his competitive Barcelona debut likely in El Clasico against Real Madrid on October 26; he must still serve the remaining eight matches of a nine-game international ban but can play in Uruguay's upcoming friendlies against Japan, South Korea, and Saudi Arabia. CAS deemed FIFA's full suspension from all football-related activities excessive, while FIFPRO expressed disappointment over the lack of reduced sanctions or mandated treatment, noting the punishment's disproportionality; Suarez's legal team called the ruling a success, and it accounts for his history of incidents, including prior biting bans and a racial abuse suspension.

On 18 March 2014, Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a wife-carrying race by defeating Lithuanian competitors Vytautas Kirkliauskas and his wife Neringa Kirliauskiene, attributing their success to a week's training on a local athletics track despite strong competition from the Lithuanians. The 380-metre course involved hurdling haystacks, climbing a steep slope, and dodging water pistols, with participants not required to be married and including diverse pairings such as men carrying women, men carrying men, and one woman carrying a woman. The victors will now represent at the World Championships in Finland in July.

Stephen Hammond, in a letter to Swansea East AM Mike Hedges, addressed concerns about potential job losses at the DVLA's Swansea centre following Chancellor George Osborne's announcement in the Autumn Statement to scrap paper car tax discs in October 2014 and replace them with an electronic system allowing monthly direct debit payments. Hammond stated that the changes would likely reduce refunds and lead to alterations in job roles, requiring training on new processes, but any staff reductions would be managed through redeployment to other growth areas rather than redundancies. Hedges welcomed the assurances, noting they would comfort the 5,000 DVLA employees, while acknowledging the benefits of the new system despite disappointment over fewer job opportunities.

Hungary's Foreign Minister Peter Szijjarto stated that the EU should not interfere in domestic issues and confirmed no backtracking on controversial laws regarding asylum seekers, NGOs, and higher education, which critics say could force the closure of the Central European University founded by George Soros. He noted Poland's commitment to veto any EU attempt to strip Hungary of voting rights, as such decisions require unanimity. The EU objects to Hungary's tight controls, including housing asylum seekers in shipping containers and proposed NGO legislation that would label them as foreign-backed, amid ongoing protests in Hungary and pressure from EU officials like Frans Timmermans to withdraw the laws, two of which have already passed.

Adrian Anthony Gill, known as A.A. Gill, a renowned British columnist and restaurant critic for the Sunday Times since 1993, died from an aggressive form of cancer he humorously termed the "full English," which he revealed last month while undergoing chemotherapy, expressing no regrets and feeling lucky in life. Editor Martin Ivens described him as a "giant among journalists" with incomparable wit, dazzling writing, and compassion, noting his sudden death shocked colleagues, and his final column on his diagnosis will appear in the next edition. Tributes poured in from figures like Jay Rayner, Tim Shipman, Stig Abell, John Witherow, Andrew Neil, and Piers Morgan, praising his brilliant, fearless style despite his controversial pieces that sparked outrage, including shooting a baboon in 2009, derogatory remarks about the Welsh, various UK regions, and a homophobic slur against Clare Balding in 2010. Born in Edinburgh in 1954, Gill overcame dyslexia to build a career starting with art reviews for magazines and Tatler, often dictating his work; he studied at St Christopher School and art colleges in London, was married twice—first to Cressida Connolly, then to Amber Rudd (now Home Secretary) with whom he had two children, Flora and Alistair—and recently got engaged to longtime partner Nicola Formby, mother of his twins Edith and Isaac, prompted by his illness.

Mongolian rapper Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, known as Amraa and lead singer of the band Khar Sarnai, was allegedly assaulted while performing in Ulan Bator, wearing a traditional red deel embroidered with a swastika—a ancient symbol of eternity in Mongolia that predates its Nazi associations. Russian news reports claim he was hit over the head with a bottle and kicked in the face by an unidentified Russian diplomatic officer, leading to serious brain injuries and about 10 days in a coma. The Russian embassy is investigating but describes local reports as distorted regarding details like the date, participants, and circumstances. Sukhbaatar's father, lawyer, and band member denied social media claims that he shouted "Heil Hitler," emphasizing the swastika's cultural significance in Mongolia, where it is used in traditional patterns and by some far-right groups, though it evokes strong sensitivities in Russia due to WWII losses. Mongolian police are investigating the case, noting the suspect was not detained because the injuries were not deemed serious, not due to diplomatic immunity.

Campaigners from the action group Plane Stupid staged a protest on Monday on the northern runway of an airport at 03:30 BST, opposing the airport's expansion plans, leading to charges of aggravated trespass and entering a security restricted area of an aerodrome; the protesters will appear in court on 19 August, and the Metropolitan Police stated that airport security would be reviewed.

In a County Championship match in Cardiff, Glamorgan were bowled out for 220, with opener Nick Selman's mature 101 off 144 balls—his second first-class century—dominating their innings after he was dropped on eight and overcame a recent run of low scores, including four ducks. Aneurin Donald contributed a quick 36 off 30 balls, while Gloucestershire seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles took regular wickets in cloudy conditions, with Taylor hitting the stumps three times. Glamorgan secured a bonus point thanks to efforts from Graham Wagg and Timm van der Gugten. Gloucestershire faced a tough evening session for survival, leaving the day evenly balanced. Glamorgan were captained by Michael Hogan in the absence of injured Jacques Rudolph. Selman expressed relief at returning to form on a slow wicket, aiming to build on it, while Taylor was pleased with the bowling performance and anticipated a challenging batting innings against Glamorgan's attack.

Craig Hughes, a 33-year-old from Flint, was arrested by North Wales Police in August after making online threats via the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee, where he discussed plans to lure officers to the Dee Estuary by reporting a fake crime and then ambush and shoot them. He admitted two charges at Mold Crown Court on Friday, with sentencing set for next week, and was remanded in custody by Judge Niclas Parry, who noted his prior 2009 conviction for possessing a firearm. The threats occurred twice late at night while Hughes was drunk, and although he was on bail for unrelated firearms offences (of which he was later cleared), his legal team stated he had no intention of harming himself or carrying out the threats against police. The Hope Line provides confidential support and counselling for those in difficulty.

Surrey recovered from an early collapse to 8-2 to post 255-7 against Yorkshire, thanks to a 130-run partnership between Davies and Ben Foakes (90), with Davies benefiting from a dropped catch to score aggressively before falling. Yorkshire's chase started well but was derailed by Stuart Meaker's three-wicket burst in nine balls, dismissing Jonny Bairstow (13), Gary Ballance (32), and Jack Leaning, leaving them at 236 all out despite Tim Bresnan's 68 and Matthew Waite's 38. This defeat ended Yorkshire's hopes of reaching Lord's for the first time since 2002, following their recent T20 Blast semi-final loss to Durham. Surrey captain Gareth Batty praised the team's unity and the key partnership that opened up the game, while noting they could have scored more, and Yorkshire skipper Alex Lees expressed disappointment, highlighting the failure of the top order despite strong bowling and a chaseable target.

A 56ft (17.1m) converted trawler, located 6 miles (10 km) west of South Stack, experienced flooding when its onboard pump failed to handle incoming water, prompting the crew to radio Holyhead coastguards at 07:00 BST; the RNLI lifeboat crew responded by deploying an additional pump and towing the vessel to Holyhead.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old Scottish middle-distance runner, will miss next year's Commonwealth Games on Australia's Gold Coast due to her final-year veterinary medicine studies and exams in May, prioritizing her degree despite being gutted about not representing Scotland. She finished fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, achieving a new outdoor personal best of 14:52.07 in the latter, where Hellen Obiri won gold by upsetting defending champion Almaz Ayana, with Sifan Hassan third; Muir expressed delight with her performance amid tough competition and fatigue from five races in 10 days. While returning to university soon, she sees potential for at least two or three more Olympics and considers the March World Indoor Championships in Birmingham as a possible target, confident in her shape and the Scottish team's success.

Robbie Savage analyzes Liverpool's decline since last season's title challenge, attributing it to the loss of Luis Suarez, Daniel Sturridge's injuries, and inadequate striker replacements like Mario Balotelli, Rickie Lambert, and Fabio Borini, who lack goals, work-rate, and pressing intensity, leading to fewer first-half goals, reduced midfield runs, and poor set-piece performance. Defensively, persistent issues remain despite heavy spending on players like Dejan Lovren and Mamadou Sakho, with no clear leader and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet failing to command his box, though stats show no improvement or decline. Savage suggests a lineup against Chelsea featuring Mignolet, Johnson, Skrtel, Toure, Moreno, Can, Gerrard, Sterling, Coutinho, Lallana, and Borini, emphasizing solid midfield and full-back balance, but predicts a Chelsea win due to their superior form. He discusses Steven Gerrard's future, noting the mental and physical challenges at 34 after his infamous slip against Chelsea, yet affirms Gerrard's fitness, importance, and potential for a long-term role at Liverpool or elsewhere, praising his resilience and all-around midfield prowess.

East Ayrshire Council plans to build a £45m educational campus at Sutherland Drive in Kilmarnock, incorporating primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare centre, and intends to seek permission from the McIlvanney family to name it after the renowned writer William McIlvanney, who was born and educated in the town and was passionate about quality education for young people. Council leader Douglas Reid expressed delight in preserving McIlvanney's name in Kilmarnock. McIlvanney, who graduated from Glasgow University and initially worked as an English teacher before becoming a full-time writer in 1975, gained fame with his debut novel Remedy Is None and earned the title "Godfather of Tartan Noir" through works like the Laidlaw trilogy, Docherty, and The Big Man, often set in Glasgow. He was also an influential poet, journalist, and broadcaster who contributed to Scotland's political and sporting discussions via columns and TV programs, and he died at his Glasgow home on 5 December.

An area near a swimming pool in Gourock was evacuated for most of the morning and early afternoon due to a sea mine spotted on Monday, believed to be a British device from the 1940s or 1950s, with an exclusion zone remaining on the river while experts make it safe. Nearby residents within 500m were advised to open windows, stay indoors near walls, and avoid going outside, affecting three streets, while a half-mile exclusion zone at sea prevented small boats from sailing and caused disruptions to Caledonian MacBrayne ferry services between Gourock and Rothesay. Police commander Ch Insp Elliot Brown described the evacuation as precautionary with no immediate danger to the community, and Royal Navy Lt Cdr Tim Castrinoyannakis noted the mine's deterioration made it impossible to assess remaining explosives, leading to its relocation for safe handling. Inverclyde Council thanked residents and businesses for their patience during the cordon and evacuation procedures.

UK Sport has allocated £345 million for 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports ahead of Tokyo 2020, a slight reduction from the £347 million for Rio, setting medal targets of 51-85 for Olympics and 115-162 for Paralympics after Britain's record 67 Olympic and 147 Paralympic medals in Rio. Funding cuts affect several sports, including complete withdrawal for badminton despite its Rio bronze, alongside archery, fencing, weightlifting, and wheelchair rugby, while cycling's budget drops by over £4 million to £25.98 million; judo sees a slight increase. Badminton officials expressed shock and vowed to fight the "incomprehensible" decision, citing its catastrophic impact, as UK Sport prioritizes medal potential amid limited resources. Team sports like basketball, handball, and volleyball criticize the lack of support, accusing UK Sport of neglecting their development. Funding for new Tokyo sports—such as baseball/softball, karate, skateboarding, sports climbing, surfing for Olympics, and Para-taekwondo, Para-badminton for Paralympics—remains unconfirmed, with £9 million still to be allocated based on medal prospects, and baseball's coach remains optimistic about potential investment.

Three Victorian hotels—Bay View Court, The Cottonwood, and Ocean View—on Grove Road and East Overcliff Drive in Bournemouth's East Cliff conservation area will be demolished by The East Cliff Project LLP to build a six-storey, four-star 90-room hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks (nine-storey and seven-storey) with 122 units, aimed at boosting tourism and improving housing for older residents. Despite strong objections from English Heritage over the development's scale causing "severe harm" to the area, and concerns from 49 residents and the Ancient Monuments Society about losing buildings that retain historic character, councillors voted 7-3 in favor, with planning board chair David Kelsey noting the structures are no longer functional and that progress requires moving forward despite regrettable losses, supported by 246 letters in favor.

Pte Matthew Boyd, a 20-year-old soldier from the Royal Gibraltar Regiment originally from Carrickfergus, County Antrim, was off-duty in Brecon during training when he was fatally punched and beaten by 24-year-old Jake Vallely outside The Cellar bar in the early hours of 8 May. CCTV footage captured Vallely, who had been on a seven-hour drinking binge and boasted of being the "hardest man in Brecon," attacking Boyd, dragging his unconscious body away, and fleeing the scene. Vallely's friend Aaeron Evans was cleared of manslaughter at Cardiff Crown Court as he had left before the violence began, while Vallely is set to be sentenced on 8 December. Senior investigating officer Det Supt David Guiney described the attack as a despicable act that shocked the Brecon community and urged people to avoid violence on nights out. Boyd's family paid tribute to him as a loving, caring all-rounder with a promising career cut short, expressing enduring pain from the loss and highlighting the community's supportive response as a sign of true strength in contrast to Vallely's claims.

Andrew Travers, chief executive of Barnet Council, left by mutual agreement following an error on election day where voters were turned away from all 155 polling stations due to missing names on poll lists, with one station reporting only three of the first 30 voters registered and others told to return later. The council apologized, offered emergency proxy votes to affected residents, and launched an independent investigation to review the incident, blamed by Travers on electoral registration lists, with findings due by the end of May for public presentation to the General Functions Committee, including assessment of arrangements for the June EU Referendum. Travers stated he enjoyed his three-and-a-half years and believed implemented changes would enable the borough to thrive, while the council praised his valuable contributions; deputy chief executive John Hooton will temporarily take over as longer-term plans are arranged.

Gateshead secured a 2-1 victory over Wrexham in a football match, with Josh Gillies opening the scoring via a fine free-kick, followed by Sean Newton's equalizing set-piece for Wrexham before half-time, and Ryan Bowman netting the winner with a header from Craig Baxter's cross. Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby praised his team's second-half improvement and passing, highlighting the quality of the winning goal, while noting Wrexham's strong first-half performance. Wrexham manager Gary Mills expressed disappointment over his side's openness and missed chances in the second half, despite creating opportunities. The match featured various attempts, fouls, corners, substitutions, and offside calls, culminating in Gateshead's triumph.

The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 assesses the social and economic welfare of people over 60 in 96 countries, ranking Norway as the best and Afghanistan as the worst, followed by Mozambique, as reported on 1 October 2014.

OneWeb, in partnership with Airbus, is building a mega-constellation of at least 600 satellites, potentially expanding to over 2,000, to provide global broadband internet from orbit, with a focus on connecting every school. To achieve this, Airbus is revolutionizing satellite manufacturing with high-volume, low-cost assembly lines in Toulouse, France, and planned facilities in Florida, producing three units per shift for under $1 million each, using automation like trolley robots and scaled supplier chains. Initially skeptical, Airbus CEO Tom Enders embraced the commercial shift from traditional "gold-plated" methods. Launches begin with 10 satellites in April next year via over 20 Soyuz rockets, aiming for nearly 300 in orbit by end-2020, over 600 a year later, and 800+ by mid-decade. Facing competition from SpaceX and others, OneWeb has secured $1.7 billion in equity and emphasizes first-mover advantage. Registered in the UK's Channel Islands, it collaborates with the UK Space Agency, promising economic benefits and leading in debris mitigation by committing to de-orbit satellites within two years, with added hardware for reliability and removal adapters. While disruptive, this approach may not apply to all satellite types, as some missions require bespoke, high-end designs.

Scottish Finance Secretary John Swinney criticized the UK government's spending review for imposing unprecedented pressure on Scotland's public expenditure, claiming it will result in a 12.5% real-terms cut to the discretionary budget by 2019-20 compared to 2010-11, with 4.2% of that reduction and over £1bn in cuts still to come until 2020. He argued that Chancellor George Osborne's austerity measures were unnecessary and vowed to protect key priorities like schools, hospitals, and police, highlighting Scottish achievements such as more officers, lower crime, better education, free university tuition, and record health spending. The UK government countered that Scotland will receive £390m more next year, rising to £750m including underspend, with a nearly £30bn block grant providing stability superior to independence amid low oil prices, urging focus on new powers rather than grievances. Labour's Jackie Baillie called for Swinney to deliver a substantive long-term anti-austerity budget beyond pre-election giveaways, promising Labour's alternative with different tax decisions from both Tories and SNP.

The passage highlights the challenges faced by people with severe disabilities and their families due to inadequate toilet facilities, often leading to isolation and distress, as standard accessible toilets lack space and equipment like hoists and benches needed for those requiring carer assistance or changing on a bench. Changing Places toilets, which are larger (12 square meters) and equipped with enhanced features, address these needs, with 893 currently in the UK, but they are only recommended, not compulsory, under building standards (BS 8300:2009). Campaigners, including parents like Lorna Fillingham, Alison Beevers, and Bethan Folen, are advocating for mandatory installation in new large buildings such as shopping centers, cinemas, and stadiums, sharing stories of stress from changing on dirty floors or limiting outings, while positive examples include Arsenal Football Club's installation and pop-up solutions at events. Barriers include logistical and financial issues, especially in existing structures, but making them compulsory could ensure clarity and prioritization for accessibility, benefiting over a quarter million people and promoting inclusivity.

Italian consumers' organizations have filed a formal antitrust complaint with the European Commission, accusing McDonald's of abusing its dominant position by forcing franchisees to pay excessive rents, high fees, and sign longer-than-average contracts that prevent switching to competitors, leading to higher prices and poorer consumer choice in franchise stores compared to company-owned ones. The complaint is supported by the Service Employees International Union (SEIU) and European unions, including the UK's Bakers Food and Allied Workers Union, who urge the Commission to investigate and hold McDonald's accountable for harming franchisees, consumers, and workers. McDonald's defends its model, stating it shares risks and rewards with franchisees to provide support and create successful business opportunities, benefiting both them and customers. The European Commission will study the submission and may launch an investigation if the allegations are substantiated. Franchisees operate 73% of McDonald's restaurants in Europe, and the company earned $9.27 billion (£6.40 billion) in worldwide revenues from franchised restaurants in 2014.

A poster featuring the hashtag #prayforjosh appeared in Holywood by the A2 last week as part of a viral social media campaign supporting 13-year-old Joshua Martin from Donaghadee, County Down, who was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve during what was meant to be an appendix operation at Belfast's Royal Victoria Hospital, where doctors instead removed a large primary cancer and five smaller growths. The campaign began with the hashtag on Facebook and Instagram from Bangor Elim Church, where Josh's father serves on the pastoral staff, initially to rally prayers from the congregation but quickly spreading globally, with one update shared 948 times and viewed by over 79,000 people worldwide. Senior pastor Gary Beattie expressed amazement at the outpouring of support, including from Twitter users and Josh's classmates at Bangor Grammar, while a mystery donor funded the billboard at Holywood playing fields, highlighting widespread kindness aiding the family's shock and Josh's recovery.

The UK government has announced a shake-up of military buildings, including the closure of Brecon Barracks, a historic site since 1805 that housed troops who fought the Zulus at Rorke's Drift and has contributed to every conflict since the early 19th century, prompting strong condemnation from Brecon and Radnorshire Conservative MP Chris Davies, who called the decision abhorrent, disrespectful to history, and harmful to the area's high unemployment and thriving military tourism; he plans to launch a petition and fight it. The barracks employs about 85 civilians and 90 military personnel, with jobs not believed to be at risk, while nearby Sennybridge training ground and Dering Lines infantry school remain unaffected. Defence Secretary Sir Michael Fallon stated the reorganization will create a specialist light infantry centre at St Athan in Vale of Glamorgan, with Cawdor Barracks in Pembrokeshire now closing in 2024 (delayed from a 2013 announcement) and a Sennybridge storage depot shutting in 2025. Shadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith supported the estate restructuring but warned of impacts on livelihoods and uncertainty for affected people.

The House of Lords report warns that Britain's fishing industry, which contributes only 0.5% to GDP and employs 12,000 people, risks being marginalized in Brexit negotiations despite strong Brexit support from fishing communities disillusioned with the EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) and its equal access rules. While Brexit offers opportunities for the UK to regain control over its waters and become a major fish exporter like Norway, the report highlights complications from shared fish stocks with EU states, heavy reliance on EU exports, and imports for UK consumption, necessitating continued market access that may require trade-offs like allowing EU boats into UK waters for tariff-free trade. It recommends retaining CFP elements such as science-based quotas and international cooperation, while expressing concerns over potential fragmented fisheries management across England, Wales, Northern Ireland, and Scotland post-Brexit. Despite risks, the industry remains optimistic, citing recent favorable EU quota increases, and the government aims to balance trade freedoms with sustainable, fair fisheries management.

Edward Snowden, a 29-year-old former CIA technical worker, revealed himself as the source of leaks exposing the US National Security Agency's (NSA) Prism program, which provides massive access to individual chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, file transfers, social networking data, and phone records from companies like Verizon, including call duration, location, and numbers. The program allegedly enables "backdoor" access to servers of nine major tech firms such as Microsoft, Yahoo, Google, Facebook, AOL, Skype, YouTube, and Apple, though companies deny involvement and experts suggest access might be limited to targeted cases via court orders. US officials, including Director of National Intelligence James Clapper and NSA Director Keith Alexander, described the leaks as damaging to national security but defended surveillance as essential for preventing terrorism, with President Barack Obama noting the trade-off between security and privacy. The leaks raise concerns about data protection laws, which vary by country and often allow data sharing under legal obligations, while cloud computing enables US access to non-US data via laws like the Patriot Act and FISA. UK Foreign Secretary William Hague assured law-abiding citizens have nothing to fear, but privacy groups like Privacy International warn of widespread violations, and the EU expressed concerns seeking more details; Snowden acted due to horror at the extent of surveillance, rejecting a world where everything is recorded.

OpenAI is a new venture backed by Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services, with a $1 billion pledge aimed at advancing AI research free from financial pressures to ensure a positive impact on humanity. The organization seeks to develop digital intelligence that benefits society as a whole, acting as an extension of human will and distributed broadly and safely, while acknowledging the immense potential benefits and risks of human-level AI if mishandled. Warnings from figures like Musk, who called AI humanity's "biggest existential threat," and Stephen Hawking, who noted its potential to self-redesign beyond human evolution, highlight existential dangers, though some experts view such threats as remote; only a small portion of the funding will be used in the coming years.

L/Bdr Ben Parkinson, a Doncaster-based soldier seriously injured in a 2006 bomb attack in Afghanistan, carried the Olympic torch on 26 June, walking for nearly half an hour with assistance amid hundreds of supporters, as part of the flame's 8,000-mile, 70-day journey carried by 8,000 people to the London Olympics opening on 27 July. Despite a brain injury that initially took his speech, he has recovered to speak unaided, retaining his intelligence, humor, and caring personality, while dedicating 12 hours daily to gym and rehab, walking with crutches, and raising funds for military charities like Pilgrim Bandits, where he serves as patron. His torch-carrying has sparked phenomenal support, including over 5,000 Facebook friend requests he cannot accept due to the platform's limit, leading to 19,000 hits on updates, surges in emails, mail (some addressed simply to "Ben"), and invitations; his mother Diane described him as elated and buoyed by the responses, with thousands joining the Pilgrim Bandits site. Facebook suggests he switch to a public page or use the subscribe feature for broader access as a public figure.

In 2011, the US poverty rate remained flat at 15%, affecting 46.2 million Americans after three years of increases, following a record high of 15.1% in 2010. Real median household income declined by 1.5%, with the average poverty threshold for a family of four set at $23,021 (£14,300). Income inequality rose by 1.6% according to the Gini index, marking the first annual increase since 1993. Additionally, the percentage of Americans without health insurance decreased to 15.7% from 16.3%.

Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old short-format specialist, moved to Lancashire from Somerset in 2013 and has signed a new deal keeping him at the club until 2019. He holds records for England's three fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball ton against Pakistan last year. Lancashire's cricket director and head coach Ashley Giles praised Buttler's talent, his key role in winning last year's T20 Blast final at Edgbaston, his positive presence in the dressing room, and the benefits of his international experience to the squad. After playing in the Indian Premier League with Mumbai Indians, Buttler will return to Lancashire for their T20 Blast home game against Durham on Friday.

Four decommissioned Type 22 frigates—HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall—are moored in Portsmouth Harbour and up for sale by the government's Disposal Services Authority, with bidders registering interest by 23 January and no preservation proposals submitted. Bids are being finalized, viewings scheduled for late February and March, and a decision expected in spring, with the authority aiming to award at least one to a UK ship recycler to assess industry capacity. Portsmouth North MP Penny Mordaunt supports giving UK recyclers a chance but prefers saving at least one from scrapping, ideally as a reef for tourism to generate income, while the Ministry of Defence prioritizes the best financial return for taxpayers and declines to comment on bids due to commercial sensitivity. Originally anti-submarine specialists, Type 22 frigates evolved into versatile combatants with anti-surface, anti-submarine, and anti-aircraft capabilities, excellent command facilities, and a crew of about 280; last year, HMS Ark Royal was sold for scrap at £3m.

Since 1987, Fiji has faced ongoing racial and political instability, marked by coups in 1987 (overthrowing an Indian-dominated government), 2000 (led by George Speight, involving hostage-taking), and 2006 (a bloodless military takeover), leading to economic damage, especially in tourism, international isolation, and suspension from the Commonwealth in 2009 until reinstatement after democratic elections in 2014. The population, primarily on Viti Levu and Vanua Levu, is split between indigenous Fijians (now a slight majority due to Indo-Fijian emigration following unrest) and Indo-Fijians (descendants of Indian laborers), with deep informal segregation and small minorities like Chinese and Rotumans. As a former British colony, Fiji's diverse economy depends on sugar and tourism for foreign exchange, alongside mining (gold, silver, limestone), services, and light manufacturing, but it struggles with trade and budget deficits, making it a major per capita aid recipient.

Syria's Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad stated that the country is committed to destroying its 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons under a UN-backed plan, with all weapons to be eliminated by the end of June, but missed a deadline to hand over its stockpile due to attacks by terrorist groups on shipments en route to the port of Latakia, with only 4% (30 tonnes) removed so far amid security concerns acknowledged by the OPCW. The US expressed concern over delays and urged responsibility, while Russia called for completion of transfers to the coast by March 1. Mekdad rejected US criticism of barrel bomb use in Aleppo as unacceptable, insisting Syria is defending against terrorists and has not targeted civilians, despite reports from the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights of 246 deaths, including 73 children, in five days, and activist claims of 14 killed in one district. The government denied rebels seized Aleppo's central prison, which holds at least 3,000 detainees in poor conditions, though opposition sources say the Islamic Front, including Ahrar al-Sham and al-Nusra Front, freed hundreds and now control it, with fighting ongoing.

The Booker Prize shortlist for its 46th year features six novels, marking the first time it's open to all English-language authors regardless of nationality, with the winner to be announced at London's Guildhall. Neel Mukherjee's "The Lives of Others," a family saga set in 1960s Calcutta amid political activism, is the 5/2 favorite, followed by Richard Flanagan's WWII love story "The Narrow Road to the Deep North" at 3/1. Other nominees include British authors Howard Jacobson's futuristic "J," Ali Smith's dual-narrative "How to Be Both," and Americans Joshua Ferris's atheism-themed "To Rise Again at a Decent Hour" and Karen Joy Fowler's family tale "We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves," the best-seller with over 55,000 copies sold. The shortlist announcement spurred sales spikes, such as Mukherjee's book jumping from 97 to 507 weekly copies. Critic David Brauner called it a weak list, praising Jacobson's work but noting potential reluctance for a repeat winner, amid debates on literary merit versus readability. The judging panel, chaired by AC Grayling, includes Sarah Churchwell, Jonathan Bate, Daniel Glaser, Alastair Niven, and Erica Wagner; shortlisted authors receive £2,500 and a bound edition, with the ceremony presented by the Duchess of Cornwall and covered on BBC.

A celebrity known as PJS, who has young children and a spouse in the public eye, is appealing to the UK Supreme Court against a Court of Appeal ruling that lifted an injunction banning his identification in England and Wales media over alleged extra-marital activities. The Supreme Court will hear arguments on whether to grant the appeal and decide its outcome, with an interim injunction remaining in place until the hearing concludes. The case stems from PJS's occasional sexual encounters with AB starting in 2009, a 2011 text discussion about a three-way with AB's partner CD, and a subsequent three-way encounter, after which AB and CD approached The Sun on Sunday in January to publish the story. Initial High Court refusal of an injunction was overturned on appeal, but the ban was later lifted by the Court of Appeal due to widespread publication in the US, Scotland, and online, rendering confidentiality lost and efforts to remove breaches hopeless, despite PJS's arguments for privacy rights.

Fosse Park, a retail site near junction 21 of the M1 that opened in 1989, was acquired in August for £345.5m by Crown Estates, with plans underway to enhance parking, alleviate traffic congestion, and improve the appearance of its units. Ernie White, leader of Blaby District Council, noted that the new owners have consulted the council on planning matters, viewing the park as a key gateway from Blaby into the city and an opportunity for investment to replace the current unappealing view of shed backs. Paul Clarke, Crown Estates' director of investments, emphasized addressing the park's tired state by upgrading common areas for walking and parking, along with overall facilities, to optimize its quality.

The live-action remake of Beauty and the Beast sparked controversy in Malaysia due to a "gay moment" involving the character LeFou, who grapples with feelings of lust and admiration for antagonist Gaston. The film, originally set for release on Thursday, was delayed for content review by Disney, but the Malaysian Censorship Board (LPF) approved it with a minor edit to the scene and a P13 parental guidance classification, despite homosexual activity being illegal in the Muslim-majority country. LPF Chairman Datuk Abdul Hamid confirmed the approval, noting that screening dates and locations are not under their jurisdiction, while local cinemas offered refunds for advance tickets. The tourism minister deemed any ban "ridiculous," and netizens criticized the decision as "stupid and laughable," highlighting perceived inconsistencies with other local films lacking moral values. No new release date has been announced.

Landlords renting properties to more than three unrelated people must obtain a House of Multiple Occupation (HMO) licence, though many avoid it due to costs up to £1,000, risking fines of up to £20,000, according to Southampton City Council, which estimates 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the area. Shelter adviser Nadeem Khan notes frequent tenant concerns about eviction fears and poor maintenance in unregulated rentals, driven by a shortage of affordable housing, with the helpline receiving about five or six such calls daily. Nationally, mandatory HMO licensing applies to houses of three storeys or more occupied by five or more unrelated people, while in Southampton, it covers specific wards including Bargate, Bevois, Portswood, Swaythling (introduced 2013), and Shirley Freemantle, Millbrook, Bassett (introduced 2015). The council reports general landlord cooperation but resistance from a small minority, leading to prosecutions against one firm and 13 individuals.

Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny of Fine Gael and Micheál Martin of Fianna Fáil are seeking to avoid a second election in Ireland, with Martin stating that his party will facilitate a minority government but not support a programme for it. Water charges remain a key obstacle to agreement, with proposals including a commission to examine the future of the national water utility Irish Water; Fianna Fáil demands their immediate removal, while Fine Gael supports retaining a role for them. Nearly two months after the election, Fine Gael holds 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23, and Labour 7, but no party achieved a majority, and TDs have been unable to elect a taoiseach.

The ferry Sorrento, owned by Italian company Atlantica di Navigazione, was en route to Valencia when a fire broke out on one of its car decks on Tuesday afternoon, about 27km from Mallorca, with the cause unclear. The blaze quickly intensified, prompting a full evacuation after initial distress signals at 13:50 local time, despite the captain's early belief that abandonment wasn't necessary. Passengers and crew were rescued via lifeboats and transferred to the ferry Puglia, one of several vessels that responded, and are being transported back to Palma de Mallorca, with arrival expected soon and psychologists on hand for counseling. At least three people were injured, one seriously, and airlifted to hospital, while Spanish officials warn the ship may sink in its current position.

The Electoral Commission reported concerns from 38 MPs about claims of people, including students, voting twice in the June 2017 general election—a criminal offence—and recommended better integration of local electoral registers to detect duplicates, along with improved online verification tools like those in Australia, New Zealand, and Ireland to reduce administrative burdens from duplicate applications. A record 46.8 million people were registered to vote, up 500,000 from 2015, with a 68.7% turnout—the highest since 1997—and a surge of 2.9 million applications in the six weeks after the snap election was called, leading to over 10% electorate growth in student-heavy areas like Canterbury and Cambridge. Despite 4.9 million applications from December 2016 to May 2017 resulting in only a 1.4 million net increase, indicating 30-70% duplicates due to disconnected databases and ease of online submission, there was no evidence of actual double voting, though the watchdog urged police reports and proposed requiring those registered in multiple constituencies to pre-select one for general elections. Labour's Cat Smith emphasized prosecuting offenders but cautioned against measures that could hinder young voters or impose blanket bans on dual registrations needed for work or study.

Lawrence Phillips, a 40-year-old former NFL player and star at the University of Nebraska in the 1990s, is believed to have killed himself early Wednesday while serving a prison term of over 30 years for convictions including assaulting a former girlfriend and driving his car into a group of teenagers. He played professionally for the St. Louis Rams, Miami Dolphins, and San Francisco 49ers until 1999, but faced ongoing troubles on and off the field, followed by further legal issues after his career. Recently placed in solitary confinement after being accused of killing his cellmate Damion Soward, 37, Phillips was ruled eligible for trial in Soward's death by a judge on Tuesday, though the method of his suicide remains unclear. His former Nebraska coach, Tom Osborne, described him as intelligent with good qualities but unable to overcome anger issues and personal demons.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram serving as the mascot of the Mercian Regiment, was promoted to lance corporal for good behavior at a Chester event commemorating the regiment's eighth anniversary, with the honor bestowed by Colonel Brigadier Andrew Williams. As the 30th in a lineage of rams dating back to the mid-19th century Indian Mutiny War, the tradition began in 1858 with the 95th (Derbyshire) Regiment of Foot and continued when the Mercian Regiment formed in 2007. Officially classified as a soldier, Derby XXX joined in February 2014, holds his own army number, receives pay for rations, and takes holidays during mating season at the Chatsworth Estate in Derbyshire; his duties have included switching on Ashbourne's Christmas lights and meeting Prince William at a 1914 Christmas Truce memorial unveiling.

Liverpool secured a dramatic 4-3 victory over Borussia Dortmund in the Europa League quarter-final at Anfield, advancing to the semi-finals with a late injury-time header from Dejan Lovren, completing a stunning comeback after trailing 2-0 early due to goals from Henrikh Mkhitaryan and Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang, and later needing three goals in 33 minutes following Marco Reus's strike. Inspired by manager Jurgen Klopp's philosophy of turning doubters into believers and invoking the spirit of the 2005 Champions League final comeback in Istanbul, Liverpool fought back with goals from Divock Origi, Philippe Coutinho, Mamadou Sakho, and Lovren, fueled by an electric atmosphere including a prolonged "You'll Never Walk Alone" and a minute's silence for the Hillsborough disaster's 27th anniversary. Despite Dortmund's class and Liverpool's defensive vulnerabilities, Klopp's intense touchline presence and the fans' noise broke the visitors, imprinting his identity on the team and boosting confidence for potential Europa League success, which could earn Champions League qualification, with semi-final opponents including Sevilla, Villarreal, and Shakhtar Donetsk.

Following a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee in London, UK Brexit Secretary David Davis pledged to keep Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland informed about EU exit negotiations through monthly meetings for a two-way flow of information and analysis, allowing devolved administrations to voice their views as the UK prepares talks with Brussels. Davis described the meeting as constructive and amicable, emphasizing collaboration to secure the best deal for the whole UK while implementing the referendum decision to leave the EU. Scottish Minister Mike Russell welcomed the involvement process but criticized the UK government's lack of transparency and clarity on strategic intentions over four months post-referendum, particularly regarding access to the EU single market and customs union, which he stressed is essential for Scotland's economic prosperity. The UK government hopes to overturn a High Court ruling on triggering Article 50 via a Supreme Court appeal next month, while the Scottish government plans to oppose this, with Lord Advocate James Wolffe seeking to be heard in the case.

Veterinary surgeon Dr. Sandra Corr examines Daisy, a cloned sheep, for signs of joint heat, swelling, crepitus, or lameness that could indicate disease or osteoarthritis. Daisy is one of 13 cloned sheep at the University of Nottingham, and among four (Daisy, Debbie, Denise, Diane) cloned from the same adult ewe as Dolly, the first cloned mammal born in 1996, effectively making them Dolly's identical twins. Led by Professor Kevin Sinclair, the study investigates whether cloned animals age normally or suffer premature aging due to "age-memory" transferred from adult cells, potentially leading to early onset of age-related diseases. Dolly's death at age six-and-a-half from a virus and osteoarthritis prompted the creation of these clones to determine if such issues stem from cloning. The sheep undergo rigorous tests, including physical exams, X-rays, and fMRI scans, focusing on cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis. Now approaching nine to ten years old, these clones appear healthy, with study results set for publication next week, potentially impacting the future of cloning science.

Shutter Speed, the unbeaten 4-7 favourite trained by John Gosden, won the Musidora Stakes by a length and three quarters over Vintage Folly on soft ground, marking a fifth victory in the race for both Gosden and jockey Frankie Dettori, who noted she handled the conditions but would perform better on firmer ground and praised her class. Instead of the Epsom Oaks, where stablemates Enable and Coronet are top contenders, Shutter Speed will head to Chantilly for the French Oaks over a mile and a quarter, giving Gosden a month to prepare her. Meanwhile, Tasleet (14-1), trained by William Haggas and ridden by Jim Crowley, comfortably won the Duke of York Stakes ahead of Magical Memory and Comicas. Gosden expressed concerns about the soft ground for his colt Cracksman in Thursday's Dante Stakes, a Derby trial, and will walk the course before deciding whether to run him, especially given the short 16-day gap to the Derby and the race's demanding quality.

The British pound experienced volatility amid Brexit referendum uncertainty, initially slipping against the dollar, euro, and yen before a partial mid-afternoon recovery and subsequent decline, ending down 0.2% at $1.4226 versus the dollar, 0.6% at €1.2605 against the euro, and 1% against the yen at just over 151. The volatility index reached 2008 crisis levels, driven by polls showing Leave ahead and the implied Remain probability dropping to 68.5% from nearly 80%, with 10 days until the vote. Investors were rattled by falling Remain odds and global economic concerns, prompting hedge funds to short-sell sterling and analysts to predict heightened pound movements if the race remains tight. Asian markets fell sharply, with Japan's Nikkei down 3.5% and Hong Kong's index down 2.5%, while London's FTSE 100 closed 1.1% lower at 6,044.9, led by a 4.2% drop in Lloyds Banking Group. Leave campaigners, including Nigel Farage, argued the pound had retreated to March levels, noting a weaker currency benefits UK exporters, as evidenced by April's narrowed trade deficit due to rising exports, amid broader discussions on EU membership's impact on trade and the economy.

Braintree Town, known as The Iron, sit sixth in the National League, one point outside the play-off positions, following a defeat to Barrow that extended the latter's unbeaten league run to nine games and Braintree's losing streak to three. Manager Cowley praised his team's performance despite a tough start, conceding early after a long six or seven-hour journey, noting they posed many questions to a strong Barrow side.
