He highlighted the remarkable achievements so far for the part-time team, emphasizing that the journey won't be easy but they will embrace and enjoy the toughest challenge yet.

From April 2015, local councils in Northern Ireland will assume responsibility for most planning decisions, allowing elected politicians to approve or reject developments like new houses or extensions in their areas, shifting power from the central Planning Service under Stormont's environment department. This change is viewed positively by Michael Corr of PLACE as an opportunity for councils to create community development plans and for voters to elect politicians skilled in urban regeneration. However, concerns arise from historical discrimination in the 1960s, which fueled the Civil Rights movement, with Friends of the Earth's James Orr warning of potential favoritism toward certain communities, influenced by close ties between developers and political parties, and emphasizing the need for a strict code of conduct, transparency, and public disclosure of political donations. Debates on donation transparency persist, with a £7,500 declaration limit considered irrelevant by some, and the decision on revealing donors left to the Northern Ireland Secretary amid security worries for donors.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was found injured in Winchburgh, Scotland, on March 14 after being shot twice in the shoulder and once in the left back leg with an airgun, necessitating amputation of the leg by vets, who described her survival as incredibly lucky. Owner Sarah Nisbett expressed distress over the cat learning to hop around and highlighted safety concerns in a housing estate with children, calling the act by a "sick" person alarming and urging reports to authorities. The Scottish SPCA, investigating the incident, emphasized the need for urgent airgun licensing to restrict ownership to those with legitimate reasons and aid police in tracing irresponsible use, noting a prior government consultation where 87% of respondents opposed the plan, deeming it draconian, though some felt it insufficient. The charity appealed for information on the perpetrator to prevent further harm.

Liverpool have signed Belgian striker Christian Benteke from Aston Villa on a long-term contract, making him their second most expensive signing and seventh of the summer, after triggering his release clause following the £49m sale of Raheem Sterling to Manchester City. The 24-year-old, who scored 49 goals in 101 games for Villa since joining from Genk for £7m in 2012, expressed excitement about joining to win trophies and be part of manager Brendan Rodgers' project. Liverpool aimed to boost their attack after struggling for goals last season, finishing sixth in the Premier League following Luis Suarez's £75m move to Barcelona and Daniel Sturridge's injuries, with signings Mario Balotelli and Rickie Lambert contributing just three league goals; other new forwards include Danny Ings, Roberto Firmino, and returning loanee Divock Origi. Benteke, who missed the 2014 World Cup due to an Achilles injury but scored 15 goals upon returning to help Villa avoid relegation and reach the FA Cup final, is praised by former Villa manager Paul Lambert as a brilliant number nine who thrives on service and can handle Liverpool's expectations, and by ex-Liverpool striker John Aldridge for his speed, strength, aggression, and potential to improve on last season's eight goals from strikers.

A study commissioned by Tablets for Schools found no clear evidence that tablet devices improve academic performance, despite their widespread use in 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools, with 9% providing one per pupil and highest adoption in academy schools. Tablets are projected to increase from 430,000 to nearly 900,000 in schools between 2014 and 2016, and while researchers cannot isolate their impact on attainment, head teachers report benefits like motivating disengaged pupils and boosting family involvement. Young people are deeply immersed in technology, with many taking devices to bed for social media, a quarter of secondary pupils in tablet-equipped schools identifying as internet "addicts," and 70% of 5-15-year-olds having home access per Ofcom data. A separate study highlights touch-screens aiding reading among boys and poorer children, and educators emphasize tablets' role in empowering students, reflecting real-world tech use, with their portability and immediacy preferred over laptops.

The exhibition "Growing Up in the City" at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 evocative photographs spanning from the 1880s to the 1990s, capturing children's lives in Liverpool and providing a social history of childhood changes, including play, special occasions, and work. Highlights include the oldest image from 1887, a portrait of siblings Florence, George, and Gertie Rollo dressed for a fancy dress ball in their affluent Waterloo Park home, and a circa-1900 photo of a young maid illustrating child labor. Curated by Kay Jones of the Museum's Urban Community History, who selected from hundreds of collection items to represent both joyful street play and harsher realities, the display aims to evoke relatable memories while highlighting societal shifts and runs until 25 September.

Centre-back Myles Anderson, 27, has mutually cancelled his contract with Barrow to join National League rivals Torquay United, where he could face his former club on 18 February; the ex-Aldershot, Exeter, and Italian league player is described by Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson as a leader with stature and voice despite limited games for his age. Striker Ruairi Keating, 21, joins Torquay on the recommendation of ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams, following spells at Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps, with the move pending international clearance; Nicholson views him as young, raw, and highly motivated. Torquay currently sit four points above the relegation zone, having won just one of their last six matches.

Bolivia's new law allows 12-year-olds to work with parental authorization, aiming to address the country's poverty as one of South America's poorest nations, where over 500,000 children already work in roles like shoe cleaning, food selling, mining, and agriculture to supplement family income. Signed by Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera in President Evo Morales's absence, the legislation balances local realities with international treaties, imposes harsher penalties including 30 years in prison for child homicide, and seeks to eradicate extreme poverty under Morales's socialist government. While the International Labour Organisation (ILO) sets a minimum working age of 15 generally but 14 for developing countries and is reviewing the law for potential breaches, Garcia noted that aligning strictly with conventions would be unenforceable given Bolivia's unique needs.

Rosie O'Donnell, a 50-year-old actress known for roles in films and TV shows like Drop Dead Diva, Will and Grace, and Nip/Tuck, survived a severe heart attack known as the "widow maker" after experiencing chest aches, nausea, and feverishness following an incident where she helped a woman out of her car at her home in Nyack near New York. She researched women's heart attack symptoms online, which matched her sudden nausea and aches, took aspirin, but did not call emergency services; the next day, a cardiologist inserted a stent into her 99% blocked artery. In a blog post featuring a poem titled "my heart attack," she described feeling lucky to be alive and urged women to recognize symptoms, listen to their inner voice, and call 911, while noting her recent hosting of The Rosie Show, which was cancelled in March due to low ratings.

Che Labastide-Wellington, a boy from Harrow, was fatally stabbed in an alleyway during a scuffle at about 00:30 GMT following a party in Belvedere Way, Kenton, on Saturday evening, where he had been invited; he was pronounced dead an hour later and was not involved in an earlier altercation with youths denied entry but appeared to have been targeted later. A 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and is in stable condition in a north London hospital. Police described the party as well-run with adults present and are seeking witnesses near the alleyway between Belvedere Way and Tylers Gate. A 21-year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of murder and is in custody at a west London police station, while two boys aged 15 and 16 were arrested on the same charge and bailed until mid-December, and a 14-year-old is held on suspicion of possessing an offensive weapon.

Denmark reorganized its cancer diagnosis system over 15 years ago after alarming survival statistics revealed poor performance compared to other European countries, primarily due to long waiting times for patients with vague or hard-to-diagnose symptoms, which accounted for over 25% of 30,000 studied cases. The new model introduced three routes: fast-track pathways with strict timelines for alarm symptoms and a legal 30-day investigation requirement post-GP referral; diagnostic centers at hospitals for quick tests and scans on undiagnosable cases to avoid referrals bouncing between specialists; and "yes-no" centers for minor symptoms offering rapid tests to rule out rare serious issues, reducing delays from months to hours. This has improved organization without overwhelming resources, boosted survival rates, and helped Denmark catch up to Scandinavian neighbors. A Welsh team, noting similarities in health systems, visited Aarhus to learn from this collaborative approach between GPs and specialists for better patient outcomes.

Powys council has been selected through a competitive bidding process to replace the disbanded Office of Fair Trading (OFT) in enforcing estate agent regulations, receiving £170,000 annually to issue warnings and banning orders against agents acting dishonestly or breaching laws. This follows the UK government's decision to disband the OFT, with complaints still directed to local authority trading standards departments for potential prosecution, while cases involving breaches of the Estate Agents Act will be referred to Powys. James Munro, who will lead the new Powys team, expressed hope that this role demonstrates the council's capability for more external contracts, as discussed in his interview on Radio Wales' Good Morning Wales with Peter Johnson on 31 March 2014.

NHS Employers has approved a plan to reshape the NHS's 1.3 million-strong workforce, allowing staff like nurses and pharmacists to take on additional tasks with more training to address shortages, such as gaps in junior doctor rotas and overwhelmed GPs, as highlighted in a Nuffield Trust review that cited examples of nurses substituting for hospital doctors and pharmacists for GPs. The review emphasizes that this aligns with the shift toward managing long-term conditions like diabetes and heart disease, noting doctors comprise only one in ten staff and that more contributions from others are needed, though funding for training is essential. Report author Candace Imison sees huge opportunities for better patient care and staff roles, while NHS Employers' Danny Mortimer calls for implementing the recommendations; however, the British Medical Association's Dr Mark Porter warns against undermining doctor training and expertise, and Unison's Christina McAnea cautions that it should not be a cheap fix for chronic shortages amid funding squeezes.

Avon and Somerset Police closed the A36 Lower Bristol Road in Bath at Rackfield Place outside the First depot following a crash at 03:00 GMT, with the closure lifted at 14:00 GMT, causing disruptions and delays to commuters and bus services during rush hour. Investigations are ongoing into the collision, and Local Live provides the latest travel updates. First bus services have partially resumed normal operations, with full recovery expected in a few hours and a full service hoped for by the evening commute, as stated by managing director James Freeman, who thanked the public for their understanding and staff for their extra efforts.

Natural Resources Wales (NRW) estimated that the proposed Swansea tidal lagoon would cause 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout to die annually during migration, based on what it calls the best available evidence, though Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) disputes these figures as lacking clear scientific basis and claims NRW refused to share its methodology, instead citing its own expert modeling showing a worst-case impact of 2% on all fish species. The £1.3bn project is viewed by TLP as a prototype for larger, more cost-effective lagoons in areas like Cardiff, Newport, and Colwyn Bay, with the UK government currently reviewing its viability in an unpublished six-month study. Wales' Environment Secretary Lesley Griffiths expressed strong support for the scheme but urged quick clarity from the UK government, while NRW strongly rejected TLP's criticism, affirming that it shared extensive data and methodology over 18 months, assessed by independent and internal experts to ensure environmental protection.

Northern Ireland's DETI Minister Arlene Foster announced the establishment of a new industry-led agri-food marketing body, to be developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB), modeled after Scotland Food and Drink, aiming to provide strategic leadership for marketing efforts across government and private sectors in the vital agri-food industry, which supports nearly 100,000 jobs in farming, fishing, retail, and distribution. Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill welcomed the move, highlighting the sector's role in export-led economic growth and the need for better coordination of marketing activities as identified by industry representatives, though she noted potential implications for other organizations, including her department, and expressed interest in discussing the plans with AFSB.

The Woodland Trust is organizing a public tree-planting event on Saturday afternoon at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley, about seven miles outside Derry city off the Glenshane Road, as part of a four-year UK-wide project to create four new woods commemorating the millions who died in World War I by planting millions of native trees under the pledge "We will stand for those who fell." At Brackfield, the aim is to plant 40,000 trees as a tribute to the estimated 40,000 people from the island of Ireland who lost their lives in the conflict, inviting locals and visitors to participate in this hands-on activity to make a historical mark, with the charity providing saplings and advising volunteers to wear welly boots or stout footwear amid limited parking. Director Patrick Cregg described it as a special opportunity to contribute to the young wood, which will eventually feature carpets of wildflowers like poppies, thriving wildlife, and spaces for walking, relaxation, and reflection, serving as a living, growing tribute to the soldiers, their families, and loved ones from Ireland who played a part in the war.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award at the Harrogate crime writing festival for her book Someone Else's Skin, a thriller addressing domestic violence and honour crime, which is the first in a series featuring Det Insp Marnie Rome and was praised by judges including Alison Graham and Ann Cleeves for its emotional power, fine writing, tight plotting, and atmospheric quality. US author Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution to crime fiction award for her 23-year career creating the groundbreaking female private investigator VI Warshawski from Chicago, who was described as a game-changing action hero that transformed perceptions of female protagonists and writers; Paretsky also founded Sisters In Crime to support women in the genre. The awards were presented at the start of the North Yorkshire town's annual festival, where Cleeves, this year's programming chair, noted the strong shortlist.

Mitchell Santner, a 24-year-old left-arm batsman and spinner who debuted in Tests in 2015, is set to rejoin Worcestershire Rapids after the June ICC Trophy in England, following an injury-shortened stint in 2016 where he broke his finger in his second game. Director of cricket Steve Rhodes described Santner's previous absence as a massive blow to their qualification hopes despite a strong start, noting unfinished business with the player. Santner expressed frustration over the injury in his first T20 game but enthusiasm for returning to contribute with bat and ball among a great team. Additionally, Worcestershire signed Australian pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season across all formats in August.

Barry Pring, a 47-year-old millionaire, was unlawfully killed in 2008 by a speeding car with stolen plates and no lights while hailing a taxi on a Kiev dual carriageway, in what a UK coroner, Dr Elizabeth Earland, ruled as a deliberate act based on overwhelming circumstantial evidence, including the driver's failure to brake or stop and witness accounts describing it as intentional. Pring's much younger wife, Ganna Ziuzina (known as Anna), a former lap dancer whom he met online in 2006 and married in 2007 after a brief engagement, had left him alone to retrieve a glove from a restaurant; she quickly claimed his assets, sold his belongings, transferred funds, and was entitled to £200,000 of his estate, while evidence showed she was having an affair. Pring's family and close friend believe she orchestrated the hit-and-run for inheritance, citing her cold demeanor and laziness, though she denied involvement and did not attend the inquest despite efforts to secure her presence. Ukrainian police initially closed the case but reopened it as a murder inquiry in 2011, which remains active but not actively pursued, highlighting challenges in investigating overseas deaths.

Sophie Fearns from Litherland, Merseyside, explained that her son Charlie, who has been ill since age three, requires urgent experimental T-Cell Therapy at Seattle Children's Hospital in America after a third relapse in April left no treatment options in the UK and his previous transplant failed. The family was heartbroken by the failure but became ecstatic and overwhelmed when an anonymous donor selflessly paid for the treatment, as confirmed by an email from the hospital on Wednesday, granting financial clearance. Charlie's parents, Sophie and Rob Fearns, expressed profound gratitude for the donor's generosity, noting they expected to fundraise intensely again, and now anticipate starting the treatment as soon as possible, with a date expected next week.

Apple has introduced two-step verification for iCloud backups to prevent unauthorized access, following hacks where third-party software like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker was used to steal celebrities' intimate photos by downloading data without full authentication. The system requires users to enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted device after inputting their username and password on a new device, with a 14-character recovery key available for access if the trusted device is lost, though it's opt-in rather than default, prompting experts like Prof Alan Woodward to recommend making it mandatory across tech companies. Elcomsoft's owner, Vladimir Katalov, confirmed the update blocks his tool from accessing backups or device lists and adds email notifications for downloads, but raised concerns about the recovery key being easily lost or stolen, potentially locking users out or enabling further breaches. Apple CEO Tim Cook emphasized increasing user awareness and encouragement for enabling two-factor authentication and stronger passwords, viewing it as a responsibility beyond engineering.

Dan Groves stated that the finer details of a potential deal for 30-year-old Mark Wright to purchase 20% of Billericay Town and become a club director are yet to be finalized, as reported by The Sun. The club currently sits eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points behind a play-off spot. Wright, who finished as runner-up on I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here in 2011, has a background in non-league football with clubs like Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds. Billericay was recently acquired by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who expressed comfort in investing £10,000 weekly, and the club signed 35-year-old former England international Paul Konchesky in early March.

Mr. Ashley, owner of Sports Direct and Newcastle United Football Club, has been requested to give evidence before the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee, chaired by Hartlepool MP Iain Wright, regarding the treatment of low-paid workers and national minimum wage enforcement at the company's Derbyshire warehouse, following a BBC investigation. Ashley invited the committee to meet at the company's Shirebrook base, but the committee insists on a public session at Westminster and has offered alternative dates, which he has not accepted. He has until 21 March to respond and agree to attend, or the committee may escalate the matter, potentially seeking House of Commons support for contempt. Sports Direct has not commented on the BBC's request and previously pledged to review worker rights under Ashley's oversight.

Following the assassination of Russian opposition politician Boris Nemtsov, who began compiling a report on Russia's involvement in Ukraine after learning that relatives of deceased soldiers were denied promised compensation, his colleagues, led by Ilya Yashin, completed and released the document titled "Putin. War." Drawing on existing media reports since the March 2014 annexation of Crimea and the outbreak of conflict in eastern Ukraine, the report accuses President Vladimir Putin of orchestrating the war to boost his popularity, detailing evidence of Russian troops and equipment being pivotal to pro-Russian rebels' victories in Donetsk and Luhansk, with soldiers admitting direction by Russian generals rather than separatists. It highlights paid "volunteers" earning up to $2,000-3,000 monthly, estimates Russian spending at 53 billion roubles ($1 billion), and includes documentation of military units and weaponry photos, though verification is challenging. Despite Russia's denials of official involvement, the opposition faces hurdles in publishing and distributing the limited 2,000-copy run due to fearful publishers, and questions remain about public interest in these facts, already available online, as some Russians view the intervention as legitimate support for independence seekers, while Nemtsov's prior reports on corruption and the Sochi Olympics failed to spark widespread protests.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, a 34-year-old from Wath-Upon-Dearn in Rotherham, was found at the Woodhead Tunnels off the A628 in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on Monday, with a post-mortem examination determining he died from head injuries. A 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield by South Yorkshire Police and remain in custody.

Carwyn Jones, Wales' First Minister, expressed frustration that he was not shown or allowed to contribute to Theresa May's Article 50 letter before its publication, viewing it as disrespectful to devolved administrations despite prior general discussions with the Prime Minister. Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns defended the UK government's approach, noting May's recent visits to Wales, ongoing talks, and the letter's specific mention of Wales, emphasizing actions in the UK's overall interest. The letter promises consultation on repatriating EU powers, expecting a significant increase in decision-making for devolved bodies like those in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland, though specifics on which powers—such as farming or economic aid—and accompanying funding remain unclear, with Jones fearing a post-2020 funding shortfall. While some in Whitehall suggest centralizing certain powers due to past EU fund usage in Wales, more details may emerge in an upcoming white paper on the Great Repeal Bill, leaving the exact powers to be devolved a mystery.

Two cars were damaged in an incident in the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry on Friday night, involving attacks on PSNI officers who were carrying out their duties. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin expressed being appalled by the mindless attacks on the officers and the Newry community, while a PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook post appealed to parents to monitor their children's whereabouts and activities.

Mr. Charney, the founder of American Apparel, was ousted last year due to employee complaints and accusations of misusing company funds, and a recent San Francisco court filing by the board states they do not expect him to return, citing evidence of his illicit emails to female employees, racially derogatory taunts, and repeated violations of the company's sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policies. The filing responds to Charney's defamation lawsuit against the company and its chair, with the board arguing that his conduct poses too great a risk for any company to hire him as CEO, executive, or employee. Charney's lawyer, Keith Fink, claims many statements in the filing are false and accuses the company of invading Charney's privacy to extort and gain leverage over him. Earlier this month, American Apparel obtained a restraining order barring Charney from making negative press statements about the company or attempting to remove board members.

Great Britain faces Greece in a basketball rematch at the Copper Box in London, offering GB a chance for revenge after losing 92-64 in Patras earlier this month, with three key Greek players absent. GB guard Teddy Okereafor expressed excitement about playing in his hometown area of Stratford, noting it's crucial preparation for EuroBasket 2017 and will feature debuting players amid a great atmosphere. This is Britain's sole home game before the FIBA EuroBasket 2017 tournament begins in September in Istanbul, Turkey, followed by a four-team warm-up event in Poland. Coverage is available from 17:30-19:30 BST on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app.

The passage recounts the author's experience covering the 2007 iPhone launch by Steve Jobs for the BBC, where he obtained a brief hands-on with Apple's marketing chief Phil Schiller's device for a news segment, drawing criticism for overhyping a product but defending it as potentially revolutionary like the Model T Ford. Reflecting a decade later, the author affirms the iPhone's transformative impact as the key technology of the era, enabling powerful computing for over two billion people, disrupting industries, and revolutionizing activities like photography—illustrated by comparing his poor 2007 SLR photo of Jobs to a superior 2017 iPhone shot that could be instantly shared. While noting prior phone features like cameras and internet, the author credits Jobs' intuitive user interface for making advanced mobile use accessible and appealing, marking the start of the mobile connected era, with companies like Amazon and Google now advancing it through AI innovations.

In Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, several cats near Victor Avenue have died after ingesting a toxic substance confirmed as antifreeze, with the latest case involving seven-month-old Meereen, who died on Monday after showing symptoms like shivering and foaming at the mouth; her devastated owner, Adria Pearce, took her to the vet where the poisoning was verified, and the cat passed away three days later. Three other cats in the area died in the last seven days, and another died two weeks ago, though the RSPCA states it's unclear if the incidents were accidental or deliberate. RSPCA inspector Andy Bostock expressed concern, urging residents to store pesticides and chemicals safely, especially antifreeze used in cars during this season, by preventing leaks and cleaning up spills properly.

Despite the Syriza government's impending agreement to implement further austerity measures, VAT increases, pension cuts, subsidy reductions, privatisations, and market liberalisations demanded by creditors—measures it once opposed—there are no protests in Athens, possibly reflecting a calm before the full details of the €86bn third bailout are revealed this week. Tourism is thriving, with Athens airport anticipating 25 million arrivals this year, up from 21 million, likely due to Greece's appeal as a safe holiday destination amid regional instability. Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras, who remains popular despite failing to end fiscal austerity and exacerbating monetary constraints through bank closures and lending shortages that threaten economic activity, appears to have capitulated after July's near-collapse, embracing "there is no alternative." For the bailout to foster genuine recovery and avoid further impoverishment, creditors, particularly in Brussels and Berlin, must offer debt forgiveness—potentially reducing Greece's unsustainable debts by a third to half—rather than triumphalism.

Ross Kemp is returning to EastEnders as Grant Mitchell for a brief stint to reunite the Mitchell family in emotional scenes surrounding the death of his on-screen mother, Peggy Mitchell, played by Dame Barbara Windsor. Peggy, who left in 2010, recently returned to reveal her cancer has come back and will be killed off in spring episodes. Kemp, who portrayed Grant from 1990-1999 and again in 2005-2006, cited his close friendship with Windsor and the storyline's significance as reasons for his comeback, expressing excitement for filming classic episodes. Grant, a legendary character known for family dramas like affairs and rivalries with brother Phil (Steve McFadden), will say goodbye to Peggy alongside Phil, as highlighted by executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins, who praised the opportunity to showcase the actors at their best.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon, 26, stalked and fatally attacked 24-year-old Alice Ruggles in October, leading to his conviction for murder at Newcastle Crown Court and a minimum 22-year sentence despite his denial. Alice's parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, immediately suspected Dhillon when police informed them of her death, with Dr. Hills expressing deep guilt for reassuring Alice not to worry about the stalking and dismissing her other daughter's warnings that he would kill her, believing it was an overreaction. Prof. Ruggles noted that none of them, including Alice, fully recognized the danger despite signs. In response, the parents established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about stalking risks, hoping to honor Alice's vibrant, smiling, and cheeky personality through this effort.

French energy firm EDF approved funding for the £18bn Hinkley Point C nuclear power plant in Somerset, which is set to provide 7% of the UK's electricity and involves one-third investment from Chinese partners, with contracts slated for signing on Friday. However, hours after EDF's board vote, the UK government announced a review to carefully consider the project, prompting EDF's CEO to cancel a site visit and raising questions about post-Brexit investment and Anglo-French relations. Critics highlight risks of environmental damage, escalating costs, financial strain on EDF (evidenced by board resignations and a €4bn share issue), and foreign government involvement, while supporters urge a swift decision to secure energy supplies, meet climate goals, and boost employment. Environmental groups argue it's poor value for money and advocate for renewables like offshore wind instead. The project, proposed in 2006, gained approvals in 2013 and 2015, but the government's delay postpones the final decision until autumn.

The new divorce application form in England and Wales directly asks for the name of the person with whom the spouse committed adultery, prompting concerns from family lawyers like Margaret Heathcote and Georgina Hamblin that it unnecessarily increases conflict and complexity by involving third parties, potentially delaying proceedings and adding costs if the named individual is drawn into the court case. Although the Ministry of Justice states there is no obligation to provide the name and guidance notes emphasize it is not normally necessary, experts worry that applicants, especially those without legal advice, may fill in the box anyway, ignoring finer print, as the updated user-friendly online form replaces an older version that merely left space for co-respondents. Statistics show over 100,000 divorces were granted in 2015, with adultery cited in 12,148 cases and unreasonable behavior in 46,815, while lawyers report that 80% of adultery-related clients initially want to name the third party but are advised against it, as judges view such actions unfavorably; divorce requires proving marital breakdown via reasons including adultery.

The forestry industry in Wales, represented by Confor, criticizes ministers for prioritizing environmental concerns over commercial timber production, amid Britain's status as the world's third-largest wood importer and the loss of 16,000 hectares of commercial forest since 2001 that needs replanting. Conifer forests, a staple for half a century, support an industry worth over £450m annually to the Welsh economy, with half managed by Natural Resources Wales and half by private firms. Conflicts arise from policies favoring native broadleaf trees, public access for recreation, and wildlife conservation, which clash with commercial needs, compounded by challenges in accessing and harvesting remote forests and transporting timber through rural areas. The Welsh government aims for a balanced approach via its Woodlands for Wales strategy and Glastir scheme to promote high-quality woodlands for environmental, economic, and social benefits, though Confor's Martin Bishop highlights bureaucratic hurdles, with only 90 hectares planted last year against a needed 20,000 annually to meet targets and capitalize on strong timber demand.

A boy was badly injured after being struck in an incident in Coatbridge, with emergency crews responding to the scene on Bank Street near Langloan Primary School at around 16:40. He was transported to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow, where his condition is described as serious.

Defence attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko presented Ushakov medals to World War II Arctic Convoys veterans, including 91-year-old Able seaman Charles Lewis, who felt honored but saw himself as simply doing his duty amid what Churchill called "the worst journey in the world." The convoys involved vessels traveling from Britain to northern Russia to resupply the Soviet Union, facing severe cold, storms, ice, and constant threats from German U-boats and aircraft, resulting in the loss of 104 merchant and 16 military vessels, and over 3,000 Allied seamen's lives by May 1945. The Russian Embassy highlighted the convoys' role in providing weapons that helped defeat the Germans on the Eastern Front, symbolizing the wartime alliance. Initially blocked by the Foreign Office due to rules prohibiting foreign medals for acts over five years old, an exception was granted last year, allowing President Vladimir Putin to present the first medals in London on June 16, 2013, following the UK's creation of the Arctic Star in 2012 after veteran campaigns. The Ushakov medal recognizes sailors' courage in defending Russia or its interests.

HM Inspectorate of Probation's report highlighted significant issues with community payback schemes, where offenders sentenced to 40-300 hours of unpaid work for crimes like shoplifting or theft often face delays in starting and are frequently excused for non-attendance, with one example completing only 16 hours over 17 months. Inspectors reviewed 100 cases and interviewed 86 offenders, identifying problems such as poor organization, challenges managing offenders with chaotic lives involving drink or drug issues, and a lack of enforcement that risks either prison sanctions or ineffective sentences. The report praised some high-quality work where offenders gained skills and viewed the experience positively as a deterrent to reoffending, but criticized it as often just punishment, missing rehabilitation opportunities, and issued 15 recommendations, including reducing turnaways for on-time arrivals and tailoring objectives to offenders' circumstances. Chief Inspector Paul Wilson called for urgent improvements to ensure better delivery and enforcement, while the Ministry of Justice accepted all recommendations, pledging action to enhance rehabilitation through stricter attendance and consequences. The scheme, rebranded in 2007 with orange bibs for visibility and intensified under the 2010 coalition, involved 70,000 offenders in 2014 performing tasks like gardening, decorating, and litter-picking.

The passage discusses comedian Russell Brand being labeled a "hypocrite" by The Sun newspaper for advocating economic and political revolution to aid the poor while residing in a luxurious London home, an accusation frequently leveled against him due to his wealth and fame. It describes his spacious, airy residence with wooden floors and exposed brickwork, visible in his vlogs, and recounts an incident where, while supporting east London residents facing eviction for richer tenants outside Downing Street, a reporter questioned his own rent, prompting Brand to call the journalist a "snide" and walk away. Brand has threatened legal action against The Sun and its owner Rupert Murdoch, tweeting about the claims with #TheSunLogic, and in past statements, he acknowledges his riches and personal flaws, admits the need for individual change including wealth-sharing, but emphasizes that systemic reform is essential to address inequality and ecological issues, arguing that such hypocrisy charges distract from real problems.

Dr. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur born in 1946, transformed from a poor student and surfer into a driven scientist after his Vietnam War experiences as a medical orderly, fueling his urgency to advance genomics. At the NIH in the 1980s, he pioneered faster gene sequencing by focusing on RNA messengers rather than full DNA, leading to breakthroughs like the first complete genome of Haemophilus influenzae in 1995 at his private Institute for Genomic Research. In 1998, he founded Celera Genomics, turning human genome mapping into a competitive race against the public project, accelerating its completion by 2001 despite criticism for lacking data openness and his perceived arrogance. Wealthy from these ventures, Venter established the J. Craig Venter Institute in 2006, where after over a decade, scientists created the first synthetic life form, Synthia, published in Science. He also conducted ocean expeditions on his yacht Sorcerer II to sequence marine microbes for insights into gene evolution. Venter envisions synthetic microbes sparking an industrial revolution by producing alternatives to oil and capturing CO2 to mitigate environmental damage.

A survey commissioned by England's School Food Trust revealed that four out of five children who ate school lunches in England tried foods at school they hadn't eaten at home, with half of the approximately 1,000 parents questioned reporting their children requested those foods be prepared at home. The most popular vegetables among children were carrots, sweetcorn, and peas, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were among the least favored. Of the parents, 628 had children eating school lunches, and the research was prompted by a Mumsnet survey indicating some parents chose packed lunches due to fussy eating habits. Trust chairman Rob Rees highlighted school meals as a way to encourage trying new foods and dietary variety, while Mumsnet co-founder Carrie Longton noted peer pressure at school promotes broader eating and that meals have improved with healthier options. School meals in England must meet strict nutritional guidelines, with about four in 10 primary school children participating, slightly more than in secondary schools, compared to 46% in Scotland; the online survey targeted parents of children aged 4-17 and ran from February 26 to March 5.

Alvaro Morata, a 23-year-old Spanish striker standing at 6ft 3in, joined Juventus in 2014 after four seasons with Real Madrid, where he made his first-team debut at 18 and scored 10 goals. The transfer included an option for Real to buy him back for up to 30 million euros (£23m). During his two years at Juventus, Morata scored 27 goals, helping the team win two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias, and he played in consecutive Champions League finals—appearing as a substitute in Real's 2014 victory and scoring in Juventus' 3-1 loss to Barcelona in 2015. Previously linked with Arsenal and Chelsea, Morata is currently representing Spain at Euro 2016, where he has scored three goals.

Wilson, a 30-year-old footballer, rejoined Championship side Forest from Celtic for £2.5m in August 2013 but has been without a team since his release in May. He made 51 appearances during his second spell at the City Ground, following four prior seasons with the club before moving to Celtic, and has also had previous spells with Preston North End and Notts County.

Tesco, the world's third-largest retailer, is exiting the US market by selling its loss-making Fresh & Easy chain, which operates 200 stores in California, Nevada, and Arizona and has been unprofitable since 2007, to Yucaipa, a Los Angeles-based private equity firm run by billionaire Ron Burkle and focused on supermarket and restaurant businesses. As part of the deal, around 4,000 of Fresh & Easy's 5,000 employees will transfer to the new business, Tesco will provide an £80m loan, and while 150 stores are expected to transfer, the remaining 50 will close, costing Tesco £150m overall, though part of this is the potentially repayable loan. Tesco described the move as an orderly exit, with an option to buy a stake if the business becomes profitable, amid the company's first annual profit decline in 20 years reported in April.

The passage describes an athlete who faced initial racial abuse but overcame it, as shared in an interview with BBC Sport's Nick Hope. After briefly considering representing France, the athlete is now aiming for a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics, likely in martial arts, with a note that media playback is unsupported on the device and a recommendation to read a special guide for getting into martial arts.

The French Alps glaciers have shrunk from about 375 square kilometers in the late 1960s/early 1970s to around 275 square kilometers by the late 2000s, representing a 26% average loss over 40 years, according to a new inventory presented at the American Geophysical Union Fall Meeting by Marie Gardent from the University of Savoie and colleagues. This study assessed approximately 600 glaciers across massifs including Ecrins, Belledonne, Vanoise, Ubaye, Grande Rousse Arves, and Mont Blanc, using map archives, satellite imagery, aerial photographs, and manual verification to address issues like debris cover and shadows. The retreat mirrors trends in other Alpine regions spanning Switzerland, Austria, Slovenia, Germany, France, and Italy, but is uneven, with southern sectors like Belledonne (nearly disappeared) and Ecrins experiencing over three times the loss of northern areas like Mont Blanc, attributed to lower elevations, less precipitation, and reduced cloud cover in the south. By 1985-86, coverage had dropped to about 340 square kilometers despite a brief advance in the late 1970s/early 1980s, with acceleration since then; the largest French glacier, La Mer de Glace on Mont Blanc, has slightly decreased from 31.5 to just over 30 square kilometers. Ongoing monitoring efforts across the Alps, including Swiss reports of accelerating mass loss, highlight the broader regional decline.

Scotland's women's national football team, unbeaten with five qualifier wins, hosts Iceland at Falkirk Stadium on Friday, where a victory could secure their spot in next summer's European Championship finals in the Netherlands, avoiding play-offs after previous heartbreaks in 2013 Euros and last year's World Cup. Forward Lisa Evans, 24, from Bayern Munich, emphasizes the desperation to qualify, noting Iceland's higher ranking (20th vs. Scotland's 21st) and unbeaten record, with the upcoming home-and-away fixtures likely deciding the group winner; the best six runners-up also advance automatically. Evans highlights the emotional stakes for veterans like goalkeeper Gemma Fay and the boost from a large home crowd, while praising the squad's 12 overseas players—including herself and BBC Women's Footballer of the Year Kim Little—for gaining valuable experience in top leagues like Germany's Bundesliga, where she recently won the title and celebrated alongside stars like Franck Ribery and Arjen Robben, enhancing the team's competitiveness and diversity.

Stuart Campbell, a blogger and vocal Scottish independence campaigner who runs the Wings Over Scotland site since 2011, was arrested in the west of England on Friday after a woman in south London reported allegations of online harassment over the past two years. Released on bail until mid-September pending further inquiries by the Metropolitan Police, Campbell stated that the matter involves only some non-threatening tweets from his account, all still publicly visible and not deleted, and accused the media, including a report in The Herald, of using innuendo to fuel speculation. He tweeted about posting less frequently due to circumstances beyond his control and emphasized that nothing more sinister has occurred.

PETA is campaigning to replace Skegness's iconic Jolly Fisherman mascot, created in 1908 by the Great Northern Railway with the slogan "Skegness is so bracing" to promote seaside visits, arguing it evokes animal cruelty such as fish being hooked or crushed in nets, and suggests a fish mascot with the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice" to rebrand the resort as progressive and animal-friendly. However, Skegness Mayor Carl Macey defends the beloved mascot as happy and friendly, not portraying cruelty, and while open to suggestions that will be considered by the council, he believes there's little support for change since it's effective and not broken.

Scotland defeated Georgia in a rugby match, overcoming an early try by Georgian scrum-half Vasil Lobzhanidze to lead at halftime through tries from Tommy Seymour, a penalty try, Sean Maitland, and Stuart Hogg, with Greig Laidlaw converting several. After the break, Hamish Watson added another try, though Georgia responded with a second Lobzhanidze try from a strong scrum and penalties from Merab Kvirikashvili, while Scotland faced scrum issues leading to a yellow card for Moray Low. Scotland sealed the win with Hogg's second try on a counter-attack, assisted by debutant Ali Price and Rory Hughes. Head coach Vern Cotter praised the team's first-half dominance, ball retention, and pragmatic approach despite second-half challenges from wet conditions and Georgia's breakdown work. The passage includes full team lineups for both sides.

Widnes Vikings secured a 38-30 victory over Castleford Tigers in a Super League match, overcoming a late comeback to end a run of nine losses in their previous 10 games. The Vikings led 14-6 at half-time with tries from Macgraff Leuluai, Stefan Marsh (Ah Van), and Chris Bridge, while Paddy Flynn scored against his parent club Widnes. In the second half, Flynn added another try, but Widnes pulled ahead to 38-12 with further scores from Ah Van, Lloyd White (twice), and Joe Mellor, including one from a short kick-off error. Castleford rallied with three quick tries from Larne Patrick, Luke Gale, and Flynn's hat-trick, making it tense, but Widnes held on; Patrick had just signed a three-year deal from Huddersfield post-loan, and Flynn is on loan from Widnes to Castleford. The win moved Widnes above Wakefield into seventh place, while Castleford stayed sixth, one point ahead, suffering their fourth straight home league defeat.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old Kuwaiti detainee held at Guantanamo Bay since 2002 after his arrest in Pakistan on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban—which he denies—was released following a US Periodic Review Board's July determination that he no longer posed a continuing significant threat to US security. He had challenged his detention in the US Supreme Court and claimed he traveled to Afghanistan and Pakistan for humanitarian aid and to teach the Koran. Odah boarded a Kuwaiti government plane on Wednesday morning US time, with his lawyer expressing excitement and no bitterness about his return home, though he faces at least a year in a Kuwaiti militant rehabilitation center as part of the release terms. This marks the first Guantanamo release since May, when five Taliban members were exchanged for US Sgt Bowe Bergdahl, reducing the facility's inmate count to 148; the US opened Guantanamo in January 2002 after the 9/11 attacks, and President Obama has pledged to close it.

The viral song 'PPAP' (Pen-Pineapple-Apple-Pen), performed by Japanese entertainer Kazuhiko Kosaka as the fictional character DJ Piko-Taro, features simple, repetitive lyrics about combining a pen with an apple and a pineapple, paired with an addictive beat, silly words, and a basic dance routine. Created playfully and first uploaded to YouTube, it exploded on Facebook, with the original video garnering over 4 million views and a 9GAG version exceeding 44 million, eliciting mixed reactions from amusement and obsession to irritation among users, including comparisons to anime characters like Borsalino from One Piece. Despite limited coverage in Japanese media and social trends, it has been dubbed the next Psy-like global phenomenon, inspiring hundreds of tributes, covers, and parodies, such as those by Japanese duo Riko and Rika, a heavy metal version, and Thai star Happy Polla.

Thousands attended an early morning Anzac Day service at Hyde Park Corner in London, with up to 400 participating in a parade before wreath-laying at the Cenotaph, while another service occurred at Westminster Abbey, ending with the national anthems of New Zealand and Australia. Anzac Day commemorates the first major World War One battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces, specifically the 1915 Gallipoli landings, with the first London commemoration held in 1916 at Westminster Abbey attended by King George V. The events honor the sacrifices of countrymen and women in all wars, drawing expatriates and visitors; Australian High Commissioner Alexander Downer addressed the crowd, reflecting on the courage of Anzac troops during the Gallipoli campaign, an eight-month allied effort to force the Ottoman Empire out of the war. The parade featured veterans, service personnel, families, prayers by schoolchildren, and anthems of Australia, New Zealand, and the UK, with crowds lining the streets.

David Clarkson, a 30-year-old footballer capped twice for Scotland in 2008 with one international goal and nearly 400 senior club appearances including stints at Bristol City, Brentford, and Bristol Rovers, rejoined Premiership Well for a second spell in July after scoring nine goals at Dundee last season. He has mostly been a substitute this term but feels fully fit and ready, having maintained match fitness through U20s games and hard training, and could make his St Mirren debut in the Championship against bottom-side Alloa on Saturday. St Mirren sit eighth in the table, seven points above Alloa, and Clarkson emphasized the importance of winning games to build confidence, go on a run, and push the club up the standings.

The turkey firm Bernard Matthews was sold to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan on Tuesday, amid initial fears that the new owners might not honor the existing workers' pension scheme. However, Unite regional officer Steve Harley reported productive talks with Boparan representatives at the Great Witchingham headquarters, where guarantees were given that all current agreements would be honored. The Bernard Matthews final salary pension scheme closed in 2004, with members now under an alternative scheme unaffected by the takeover, as confirmed by the Boparan Private Office. The new owner aims to restore the business to high profitability through greater investment, cost savings, and utilizing spare capacity to process chicken in addition to turkeys.

At a council scrutiny meeting addressing issues with the new chain ferry in Cowes, council leader Dave Stewart announced free crossings until 2 July to acknowledge problems and gather feedback, while ordering an audit review of the project, describing the launch as frustrating and disappointing. Since its late May 14 debut, the ferry has experienced breakdowns, groundings, suspension by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency over training issues, and incidents of vehicle damage during boarding. Local shopkeeper Angie Booth highlighted severe trade losses for businesses over nearly six months, questioning compensation similar to that for damaged cars. Transport councillor Ian Ward stated compensation is under discussion, downplayed it as not a disaster but a prototype with expected teething problems, noting resolutions including rectified electrical issues, authorized ramp extensions to prevent scraping, and addressed seamanship for groundings.

The House of Lords report highlights risks and opportunities for the UK fishing industry post-Brexit, noting that while fishing contributes only 0.5% to GDP and employs 12,000 people, it should not be marginalized in negotiations, especially given strong Brexit support in fishing communities disillusioned with the EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) quotas and equal access rules. Brexit offers a chance to regain control over UK waters like Norway, but shared fish stocks with EU states, heavy reliance on EU exports, and imports for UK consumption mean continued market access may require trade-offs, such as allowing EU boats into UK waters for tariff-free trade. The report recommends retaining scientific-based quotas and international cooperation, warns of potential fragmentation into four separate fisheries regimes across England, Wales, Northern Ireland, and Scotland without the CFP framework, and notes industry optimism following recent favorable EU quota increases, with the government aiming for trade freedoms alongside sustainable management.

Timothy Geaney, a 69-year-old former teacher, admitted to taking or permitting indecent images of children, primarily young boys in partially dressed erotic poses without sexual activity, between April 2004 and February 2014. He received a community payback order, was placed on the sex offenders register, and ordered to participate in a special programme for sex offenders. Following a General Teaching Council Scotland hearing, he was found unfit to teach due to conduct deemed fundamentally incompatible with the profession, involving a pattern of behavior over a lengthy period with a strong likelihood of recurrence and lack of remedial action. The panel concluded he had condoned an industry that abuses children and failed to uphold professional standards, resulting in his removal from the teaching register and a two-year prohibition on re-registering; Geaney was not present at the hearing.

Following a fire on 2 March at the Duncan Street site operated by Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited (run by Asset and Land Group), firefighters remained on scene for several days, causing reduced train services and travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended the company from accepting waste and revoked its environmental permit after the blaze, with the revocation effective 7 August subject to appeal, requiring the firm to remove all waste from the site. Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS) had visited the premises nine times in the past 12 months and deemed the operators broadly compliant with fire safety laws, but raised concerns to the EA in February about potential impacts on residents, transport, and the environment, leading to joint inspections and enforcement action. The cause of the fire remains undetermined, and the company could not be reached for comment.

Syria missed a deadline to hand over its entire chemical weapons stockpile of about 1,300 tonnes, with only 4% removed so far, amid security issues including attacks on shipments by terrorist groups en route to the port of Latakia, as stated by Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad, who affirmed Syria's commitment to destroying the weapons by June under UN and OPCW oversight despite the ongoing war. He rejected US criticism of barrel bomb use in Aleppo, insisting the government is defending against terrorists and has not targeted civilians, while reports from the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights and activists claim over 246 deaths, including 73 children, in recent days from such attacks. Conflicting accounts surround an assault on Aleppo's central prison, where rebels from groups like the Islamic Front, Ahrar al-Sham, and al-Nusra Front reportedly freed hundreds of detainees from horrific conditions, though state media denies the prison was seized and says the attack was thwarted. US officials expressed concern over delays, urging responsibility, while Russia called for completing transfers by March 1.

England secured a dominant victory over Pakistan in the second Test at Old Trafford, winning by a day to spare and leveling the four-match series, with scores of 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared setting up their second-biggest win by runs margin after Pakistan were bowled out for 198 and 234. Joe Root, promoted to number three, earned man of the match honors with 254 in the first innings, an unbeaten 71 in the second, four catches, and a wicket, drawing praise from captain Alastair Cook for his controlled and extraordinary performance following self-reflection after errors in the first Test defeat at Lord's. Experts like Michael Vaughan and Geoffrey Boycott hailed England's batting quality, discipline, and bowling, noting Pakistan's broken spirit, poor shot selection, and lack of confidence, with only Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq passing 50 in the series so far. Pakistan captain Misbah expressed disappointment but hope for a comeback, as the teams prepare for a tour game against Worcestershire and the third Test at Edgbaston starting August 3, with Vaughan predicting a tight series.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is urging older people in residential care, along with their friends and families, to share their experiences as part of her review into the quality of life and care for older residents in Wales. The collected evidence will inform recommendations for care providers and public bodies, focusing on aspects like physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment, while highlighting both exemplary practices and the negative effects of substandard care. Rochira has observed positive impacts from high-quality care during her travels across Wales but has also noted increasing concerns about unacceptable variations in care quality. Her team will consult with care providers, social care staff, and public bodies to ensure accountable entities understand daily realities and implement necessary changes for optimal quality of life. Mario Kreft, chair of Care Forum Wales, supports the review's goals but expresses disappointment over the lack of a provider expert on the advisory panel, viewing it as a missed opportunity for full sector engagement and partnership.

Paul Sheerin, a 39-year-old former Aberdeen midfielder, has been appointed to replace Neil Cooper at Pittodrie after serving as player-manager at Arbroath since 2010, during which Arbroath were relegated to Scottish League Two following a bottom finish in League One in the 2013-14 season. Aberdeen chief executive Duncan Fraser stated that manager Derek McInnes selected Sheerin through a comprehensive process, and Arbroath chairman John Christison cooperated despite wanting to keep him, understanding Sheerin's desire to return to Aberdeen. Sheerin's playing career included stints at various Scottish clubs, Östersunds in Sweden, and a Scotland Under-21 cap in the mid-1990s, while as Arbroath manager, he led the team to their first national trophy by winning the Scottish Third Division title and securing promotion in 2011.

Following Bob Bradley's sacking, Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will oversee Swansea City's match against Bournemouth, as the club aims to swiftly appoint a new manager, with ex-Derby boss Paul Clement as the top choice to help avoid relegation from the Premier League. Curtis warns that dropping to the Championship would be challenging, given its increased competitiveness and no guarantee of a quick return, unlike clubs like Newcastle that can retain top players. Swansea, promoted to the top flight in 2011 after nearly facing bankruptcy and Football League relegation in 2003, built a reputation for exciting, possession-based football but has lost its 'Swansea Way' since Michael Laudrup's 2014 departure, due to frequent managerial changes, player losses without adequate replacements, and a dilution of their identity. Despite this, Curtis believes the current squad is capable of survival and educates new signings, especially foreign players, on the club's remarkable rise via the documentary "Jack to a King" to underscore the importance of staying up for the club and the local area.

Dr. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur born in 1946, overcame a lackluster youth and Vietnam War experiences that instilled urgency and a drive to become a doctor, excelling in research at the NIH where he pioneered faster gene sequencing by focusing on RNA messengers. Frustrated by slow progress and criticism, he left in 1992 to found The Institute for Genomic Research, sequencing the first free-living organism's genome in 1995, and in 1998 launched Celera Genomics to race the public Human Genome Project, completing it in 2001 amid controversy over data access but accelerating the field and amassing wealth for independent pursuits. Often vilified for his bold, immodest style and private jets, Venter established the J. Craig Venter Institute in 2006 to create synthetic life, achieving "Synthia" after over a decade, published in Science, while also conducting ocean expeditions on his yacht Sorcerer II to sequence marine microbes for insights into gene evolution. He envisions synthetic microbes sparking an industrial revolution by producing goods, reducing oil dependency, and capturing CO2 to mitigate environmental damage.

The Sutton Trust report, based on a Boston Consulting Group study, criticizes England's apprenticeship system as low-quality and too short compared to countries like Germany, with only about 200,000 of 520,000 annual starts at level three (A-level equivalent), just 20% of employers offering them versus 51% in Germany, and only 61,000 new starts for young people compared to Germany's 570,000 mostly at higher levels. It highlights that since 2010, 58% of apprenticeships are below level three, 75% target those over 25 (often already employed), 11 young people compete per spot, and England's 18,000 qualifications create a confusing patchwork versus Germany's 330. The report calls for expanding to 300,000 new starts annually, prioritizing level three or higher for at least three years, limiting level two to 10%, to boost social mobility, job prospects, and economic competitiveness, while noting poor opportunities for non-university youth. The Association of Colleges agrees on improving quality and careers advice but stresses preserving respected level two programs and the challenge of employer engagement. The Department for Education states reforms are driving up standards, with over a million apprentices since 2010, minimum one-year duration including English and maths, and further plans imminent.

Sarah Storey, Britain's most decorated female Paralympian with 22 medals (11 gold, eight silver, and three bronze) across six Paralympics in cycling and swimming, won a cycling time trial in Nottwil, Switzerland, finishing more than two minutes ahead of Poland's Anna Harkowska. The 37-year-old, who began her career in swimming with six medals at the 1992 Paralympics before switching to cycling in 2005, expressed relief at the victory and now holds 21 world titles across both sports, including four golds from the 2012 London Games. She aims for further Paralympic success in Rio 2016 and could claim a 17th title in Saturday's road race.

Hereford United, known as the Bulls, have been expelled from the Football Conference after failing to meet extended deadlines to pay £148,000 in debts to football creditors, including former manager Martin Foyle, players, staff, and loan clubs, amid total debts of around £225,000 plus £70,000 owed to HMRC. Despite dramatically avoiding relegation on the final day of the 2013-14 season by winning at Aldershot while Chester conceded an equalizer, sending Chester down, the Bulls' financial crisis led to Chester's reinstatement in the Conference Premier and Hayes & Yeading remaining in Conference South. The club, taken over by London businessman Tommy Agombar on 3 June, received multiple deadline extensions from 5 June to 12 June but could not provide required assurances, marking the first such expulsion since Chester City in 2010. Efforts like the Hereford United Supporters' Trust's offer to buy the club for £1 and clear £220,000 in debts were rejected by former chairman David Keyte, who favored other bidders, exacerbating a downward spiral since relegation from the Football League in 2012, with average attendance dropping from 3,270 to 1,758. Sympathy is expressed for fans and players whose on-field heroics now mean nothing, with some players like Kingsley James and Dan Lloyd-Weston moving to other clubs amid unpaid wages.

James Milner, a 30-year-old former Manchester City player, retired from international football after earning 61 caps for England since his senior debut in 2009, including being a squad member at two World Cups and two European Championships, though he played only three minutes at Euro 2016. He described the retirement decision as one of common sense and wished success to manager Sam Allardyce, the players, staff, and supporters. Milner also holds the record for the most England Under-21 caps with 46, starting from his first appearance in 2004, and scored his sole international goal in a 5-0 win over Moldova during the 2014 FIFA World Cup qualifiers.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and founder of the early-music movement, died at his home in Cambridge after a months-long illness, with a private funeral planned and a memorial service to follow later. He established the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, directing it for 30 years across six continents and producing over 200 CDs, including the first complete cycle of Mozart's symphonies on period instruments and a celebrated 1980 recording of Handel's Messiah, hailed as one of the top 20 recordings by BBC Music Magazine. Educated in keyboard at Cambridge University under notable teachers, Hogwood began his career as a keyboard player and musicologist with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields and as a founder of the Early Music Consort of London; he later served as artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society, and held academic positions at Harvard, Cambridge, and Cornell universities. Tributes highlighted his generosity, academic brilliance, influence in historically informed performance, and genial nature, with colleagues noting his lasting legacy in nurturing musicians and letting the music speak for itself.

A boy from Northern Ireland with special needs was removed from mainstream school in June by his parents as he was not coping, leading his mother to quit her job to care for him, and the family has been waiting for a place at a special school since then. In September, they were informed that all special schools in the South Eastern Education Board area are full with no timeframe for availability, causing the boy to feel isolated and miss social interaction, unlike his siblings who attend school. Recently, an extra classroom assistant was hired at a local special school, raising hopes he can start there soon, but his mother fears similar issues for other families due to overcapacity in the system. The Education Authority declined to comment on the individual case to protect privacy but stated they are reviewing special school needs across Northern Ireland to ensure local placements from 2016.

The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) is bidding to take over Newport Gwent Dragons, fellow tenants at Rodney Parade, which they view as a rugby venue, with a shareholder vote scheduled for May 9. Newport County holds a 10-year lease until 2023, secured after their 2013 promotion to the Football League, granting them fixture primacy if they remain in the league, and chairman Justin Foxall insists the contract must be honored. Newport RFC chairman Will Godfrey confirms that County and the Newport Squash Club are protected under existing agreements, of which the WRU is aware, though the WRU plans an artificial surface installation against Football League rules. On the field, County sits two points above League Two relegation with two games left, having won six of 10 under caretaker Mike Flynn, and can secure survival this weekend with a win and a Hartlepool loss; chairman Foxall describes potential relegation as a massive blow to fans and the city of Newport.

The passage recounts the story of a Sierra Leonean man who was kidnapped at age 15 by RUF rebels during the civil war starting in 1991, forced into violence, drug use, and atrocities like killings and mutilations, before escaping to Freetown where he lived on the streets and was briefly jailed. There, he met preacher Richard Cole, founder of the Lifeline Nehemiah project, who helped him reform, continue education, and embrace a vision of rebuilding the nation through faith and giving back. During the 2014 Ebola outbreak in Sierra Leone, which killed nearly 4,000 people before the country was declared virus-free last weekend, he contributed by educating over 10,000 people in local languages about the disease, providing food and support to 11,000 individuals in urban and rural areas, and partnering with agencies to establish a treatment unit that saved lives, despite community fears and challenges like witnessing a pregnant woman's suffering. He now regrets his past but focuses on investing in youth to change Sierra Leone and the world, with Ebola death stats including 11,314 total probable, confirmed, and suspected cases across affected countries like Liberia (4,808), Sierra Leone (3,955), Guinea (2,536), Nigeria (8), and isolated cases in the US and Mali.

A public fundraising campaign successfully raised funds in just one month to save the Wedgwood Museum's collection of about 80,000 works of art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters, and photographs from being auctioned to cover a pension debt inherited from Waterford Wedgwood plc's 2009 collapse. The Art Fund, which led the effort, will gift the collection to the Victoria and Albert Museum before loaning it back for permanent display at the museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire, following a 2011 court ruling that allowed its sale to the Pension Protection Fund after the museum entered administration in 2010. Administrator Bob Young described the outcome as incredibly satisfying, achieved through goodwill in complex negotiations, while Alison Wedgwood highlighted its importance to Staffordshire and the risk of it being scattered globally, and MP Tristram Hunt praised it as fantastic news for preserving items that chart Britain's cultural development and national identity.

Dan Groves mentioned that the finer details of a potential deal for Mark Wright to purchase 20% of Billericay Town and become a club director are yet to be disclosed, as reported by The Sun. The club currently sits eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points behind a play-off spot. Wright, aged 30 and a 2011 runner-up on I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here, has a history in non-league football with clubs like Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds. Billericay was recently acquired by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who is comfortable investing £10,000 weekly, and the club signed 35-year-old former England international Paul Konchesky in early March.

Mark Carney, Governor of the Bank of England, surprised many by extending his term for just one year beyond the original 2018 end date, opting for a "third way" instead of staying until 2021 or leaving as planned, amid Brexit uncertainties. This decision was driven by personal family circumstances, particularly his daughters' upcoming A-level and GCSE exams in 2018, prompting a desire to return to Canada for its education system, while he commits to the role's demanding nature for as long as possible. Professionally, extending to 2019 allows him to oversee the completion of Article 50 Brexit negotiations, providing market stability without abandoning the process mid-way, and he insists the choice is entirely personal, unrelated to political pressures, government tensions, or criticisms of the Bank's pre-referendum forecasts.

Blackpool and Colchester United played to a 1-1 draw in their match, with Blackpool taking the lead after 12 minutes when Jamille Matt scored from close range off a chip from Nathan Delfouneso. Colchester equalized five minutes later through Kurtis Guthrie's close-range prod following a corner scramble. Key moments included Blackpool goalkeeper Sam Slocombe's crucial saves, including denying Matthew Briggs and George Elokobi, while Guthrie hit the bar; Blackpool missed chances like Tom Aldred's header wide from a corner. The game featured several yellow cards to players including Colin Daniel, Matthew Briggs, Tom Eastman, and Andy Taylor, substitutions such as Eddie Nolan for the injured Jim McAlister and Denny Johnstone for Guthrie, and Colchester ending with 10 men after substitute Sean Murray received a straight red card for a bad tackle on McAlister in injury time.

The Healthy Me programme, developed by Northern Ireland charity Action Mental Health, targets P6 and P7 children to help them cope with changes like the transfer test and transition to secondary school, addressing stresses through interactive workshops that promote emotional wellbeing, encourage seeking help, identify support sources, and provide basic teacher training. Piloted in five schools and launched at Carrick Primary School in Lurgan, it includes techniques like breathing exercises and relaxation to build resilience amid rising test participation (14,681 entrants this year via AQE and GL Assessments, up from 14,575 in 2015). Charity CEO David Babington emphasized its role in protecting young lives from modern stresses, while teacher Helen Hamilton noted reduced anxiety for pupils and parents, aligning with chief inspector Noelle Buick's call for stronger preventative education to enhance resilience amid evolving social challenges.

The disused Fawley power station, which closed in 2013 after operating since its 1971 commissioning as a 2,000-megawatt oil-fired facility on the western shore of Southampton Water, is set for redevelopment into a £1bn "merchant city" by Fawley Waterside, featuring its 198-meter chimney as the tallest attraction south of London's Shard. The 300-acre site, sold in 2016, will include a petal-shaped glass structure, marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth, with outline planning permission expected later this year and construction potentially starting in 2018. Developer Aldred Drummond emphasized preserving the chimney as a signature element, requiring minimal investment compared to structures like Brighton's i360 or Portsmouth's Spinnaker Tower, to create a spectacular centerpiece that once powered one million homes via fuel from the nearby Esso refinery and featured 1,100 miles of internal cabling.

Chris Latham secured Great Britain's second medal at the Hong Kong world championships with a bronze in the men's points race, finishing behind gold medalist Adrian Teklinski of Poland and silver winner Lucass Liss of Germany, expressing satisfaction after a well-timed final sprint. GB earned their first medal through Elinor Barker's silver in the women's scratch, but faced setbacks including a loss to Italy for bronze in the men's team pursuit, Joe Truman's elimination in the men's keirin semi-final, and a fifth-place finish for the women's team pursuit squad, which failed to reach the medal ride. Experts like Chris Boardman and Sir Chris Hoy praised Latham's strategic ride, while Barker remained optimistic about the young women's team's potential for improvement ahead of Tokyo 2020, despite their inexperience. Olympic bronze medalist Katy Marchant was knocked out in the first round of the women's sprint by China's Lin Junhong, citing post-Rio fatigue but focusing on preparation for future events including the 500m time-trial and keirin.

Ross Kemp is returning to EastEnders as Grant Mitchell for a brief stint in Barbara Windsor's final episodes as Peggy Mitchell, who is being killed off from cancer in emotional spring scenes. Kemp, who last played Grant in 2006 after stints from 1990-1999 and 2005-2006, cited his close friendship with Windsor and the chance to reunite the Mitchell brothers—Grant and Phil (played by Steve McFadden)—with their mother as reasons for his return. Peggy recently reappeared after leaving in 2010 to reveal her cancer's return to Phil. Grant, a memorable character involved in family dramas like affairs and marital entanglements, will allow the brothers to face their mother's loss, with executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins praising it as an opportunity to showcase Kemp and McFadden at their best in classic episodes.

Sadio Mane scored twice in 138 seconds to help Liverpool defeat second-placed Tottenham Hotspur at Anfield, leaving Spurs manager Mauricio Pochettino frustrated with his team's poor start, lack of desire, and inability to handle pressure, which he said makes challenging for the Premier League title difficult. Pochettino noted that Chelsea could extend their lead to 12 points with a win over Burnley, highlighting Spurs' dismal away record, including just two road wins since September 24, defeats at Chelsea and Manchester United, draws at Arsenal and Manchester City, and only one victory in their last 17 away games against top-six sides. Former player Danny Murphy criticized Spurs' disorganized defense despite their strong record, suggesting they should have stuck with a back three formation used against big teams, and pointed out their lack of pace and poor away mindset, urging quick improvements.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) secured a major victory in Nigeria's gubernatorial elections, winning 19 out of 28 governor posts, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999, following its loss in the presidential election to APC's Muhammadu Buhari, who will be inaugurated on May 29 after defeating incumbent Goodluck Jonathan.
